bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An effective radio or telephone communication system must be maintained between the surface and underground work areas including refuge and first aid stations and at least every 600 m (2 000 ft).
The communication system must have an independent power supply.
Removal or failure of one communication device must not render the remainder of the communication system inoperative.
The employer must ensure that the minimum illumination measured 1 m (39 in) above the floor or ground level in an underground working is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 22 lux (2 foot candles) in a tunnel, shaft, incline, and haulage way, and
54 lux (5 foot candles) at a working face or other area of high activity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that an emergency lighting system or apparatus is available for every worker in an underground working so that they may exit safely.
Broken or defective lights must be replaced without delay.
A lower level of illumination, such as provided by an electric cap lamp, may be accepted for underground repair or inspection work of short duration.
Cap lamps must be kept in the worker's possession at all times while underground.

All newly purchased cap lamps, and after January 1, 1999 all cap lamps, must be capable of providing a peak illumination of at least 1 500 lux (150 foot candles) 1.2 m (48 in) from the light source, throughout the work shift.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must establish a procedure for assessing and maintaining cap lamps or equivalent portable lighting system.

If a worker is required to assess ground conditions in an underground working, at a distance greater than the effective range of a cap lamp, auxiliary lighting must be provided to safely carry out the assessment.
The employer must ensure that battery charging stations are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: effectively ventilated, and
posted with "No Smoking" and "Fire Hazard" signs.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 20 (c).]

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that air, water or discharge pipelines are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hung or secured from suitable hangers, and
located so that they are protected from moving equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the accumulation of water might affect the stability of the working or otherwise endanger workers, the employer must ensure that a suitable system is installed to remove the water.
Adequate drainage must be installed on all roadways and haulage ways.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If there may be a danger to workers from structures for storing water in an underground working, the plans and specifications must be submitted to the Board for approval before construction begins.
The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: workers are not transported in the box of a haulage, pickup or service truck, or in the bucket of a piece of mobile equipment, unless it is specifically designed for that purpose,
workers do not board or leave any vehicle while it is in motion, and
when transporting workers, underground crew vehicles are clearly identified for that purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that any railway type conveyance used to transport workers is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pulled when transporting workers,
provided with overhead and side protection, and
equipped with handrails, a non-slip floor, and an emergency exit if the conveyance is fully enclosed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A minimum clearance of 30 cm (1 ft) must be maintained between the head of a worker travelling on the track haulage vehicle and the roof of the roadway or any obstruction.
Prior written acceptance of the Board must be obtained before transporting workers on an incline or slope in an underground working by means of track haulage.
Workers must not ride on the exterior of a car, locomotive or train in an underground working.
Passenger cars hauled by mechanical means must have

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a clearance of not less than 15 cm (6 in) above the roof of the car, and
safety chains connected between the cars and between the first car and the locomotive, in addition to the normal couplings or drawbar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Workers may only ride in an appropriate, designated shaft conveyance.
When shaft sinking, workers must not ride on the rim of the bucket, or on material or equipment in the bucket.
Suitable safety staging must be installed for transporting workers in buckets over 107 cm (42 in) deep, at a level not less than 107 cm (42 in) below the rim.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appropriate written emergency procedures are established and are readily available at the worksite, and address

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: communication and emergency warning procedures,
evacuation and personnel count procedures,
fire fighting and rescue procedures,
ventilation procedures,
location of emergency equipment and procedures for use, and
other relevant information,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notices giving direction for immediate action in an emergency are posted in conspicuous places,
each person is instructed in the emergency procedures before commencing work in an underground working, and
a designated worker on each shift is responsible for implementing the emergency procedures.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must designate an emergency response coordinator with full authority to implement the emergency procedures.
A test of the evacuation procedure must be done within 3 months of commencing the project, and at least annually thereafter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A refuge station must be provided within 500 m (1 640 ft) of the main underground work area, which is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: large enough to accommodate all workers underground,
supplied with drinking water and compressed air tanks or cylinders,
equipped with a communication system to the surface,
capable of being sealed to prevent the entry of gases,
provided with a plan of the underground working which shows all exits,
maintained in sanitary condition, and
equipped with emergency lighting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When unusual conditions warrant, such as gassy underground workings, additional refuge stations may be required by the Board.

The employer must ensure that workers holding certificates of competence in underground mine rescue valid in BC, or other similar certification acceptable to the Board, who are trained in and capable of carrying out the established emergency procedures, are available for rescue operations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 3 workers when 6 to 10 workers are underground on shift;
at least 5 workers when more than 10 workers are underground on shift;

if 5 or fewer workers per shift are employed underground, or if the underground workings do not progress more than 300 m (1 000 ft), the employer must submit written rescue procedures, including details of training and availability of rescue workers, for Board approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The names and locations of trained workers must be posted in conspicuous places.
The employer must ensure that proficiency drills for workers trained in rescue work are held at least every 30 days, and are recorded in the Underground Record.

The employer must ensure that self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) for use in emergencies is available and located on the surface as near to the portal as is practicable, and capable of at least 2 hours operation.
The employer must provide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 4 units of SCBA when 10 or fewer workers are underground on shift, and
at least 6 units of SCBA when more than 10 workers are underground on shift.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Only workers trained for emergencies may enter or remain in any underground working dangerous to life or health by virtue of fire, unplanned explosion, hazardous atmosphere or other hazardous condition, and no other work may be performed until the hazardous condition has been eliminated or controlled.
Hazardous conditions described in subsection (1) must be reported to the Board.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sufficient suitable fire extinguishers or other systems of fire control are available at any underground location where a fire may occur, and that automatic systems are installed in shops and lunch rooms,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 21 (a).]

combustible liquids with a flash point below 52°C (126°F), flammable liquids, oil and grease used in an underground working are transported and stored only in metal containers or receptacles or in portable plastic containers approved for petroleum fuels, and when stored underground, unless in an approved enclosure, are restricted to a quantity sufficient for the current day's work,
any equipment repair or refueling depot is not located underground unless written permission has been obtained from the Board, and
workers do not build, start, or maintain a fire in an underground working.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 21 (d).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except when needed for burning or cutting, acetylene, propane, or other volatile fuel must not be permitted underground.

If volatile fuels are used for burning or cutting, the containers for the fuel must meet the requirements of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 (Canada), and may not have a capacity greater than 10 kg (22 lbs).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that mobile diesel equipment used in an underground working is equipped with a fire extinguisher acceptable to the Board.
The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an effective tag-in method of accounting for all workers entering and leaving the underground working is established and maintained,
at least one worker is on outside duty whenever any worker is underground,
an effective system of checking on any worker is instituted, and
trained rescue workers are identified by distinctive tags.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that any portal or collar excavation, including the slopes surrounding it, is effectively stabilized to prevent falls of material into the work area, or other effective means are employed to prevent injury to workers due to falls of material.

Prior written acceptance must be obtained from the Board before locating any structure built of combustible material, or any hazardous material storage, within 25 m (80 ft) of an entrance to an underground working.
Any support system projecting outside an underground working must be of sufficient strength to ensure that it does not break or collapse should material fall from above.
Storage facilities for hazardous liquids must be located so that spillage will not flow towards an underground working.

The employer must ensure that any part of the underground working accessible to workers is effectively scaled and stabilized, or secured to prevent entry by unauthorized persons, and is periodically inspected by a qualified person to prevent the development of unsafe conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that any active underground working is examined and, if necessary, scaled daily or otherwise stabilized as the nature of the ground and the work being performed necessitates.
The worker making the examination must, before going off shift, report to the worker's supervisor any unusual condition found that has not been corrected.

If a supervisor receives a report of an unusual condition that has not been corrected, the supervisor must, before going off shift, make a written report of the unusual condition to the underground working supervisor.
Any ground stabilization must be done by, or under the direction of a qualified person.
An adequate supply of properly sized and dressed scaling bars and other equipment necessary for scaling must be provided and maintained by the employer.
If a shoring set is required

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any loose rock or material must be scaled or adequately supported before other work is performed,
the set must be designed and installed so that the bottom section is securely anchored to prevent movement,
effective lateral bracing must be installed between sets to stabilize the support,
the set must be completely in place and secured before other work is performed, and
a damaged set that is hazardous must be repaired or replaced without delay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that shotcrete equipment is maintained in good operating condition, and that all practical measures are taken to control dust at the source during shotcreting operations.
Only those workers involved in the shotcrete operation may work downwind of the operation unless sampling shows that contaminants are within exposure limits.
When shotcrete is being applied

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the employer must ensure that any worker who may be affected by shotcrete dust is supplied with and uses appropriate personal protective equipment, and
there must be a worker at the shotcrete machine capable of immediately stopping the flow of material, in communication with the nozzle worker.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Operators of cranes or other mobile equipment engaged in ground control activities must be protected against falling, flying, or intruding objects or material, by means of suitable cabs, screens, grills, shields, deflectors, guards or structures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Whenever there is the possibility of encountering excessive water, gas, or other hazard, probe holes must be drilled deep enough to identify the hazard or at least 2 rounds ahead of the round to be blasted.
All probe results must be recorded in the Underground Record.

The employer must ensure that each underground working supervisor is provided with current development plans for the underground working supervisor's assigned area of responsibility which indicate the size, inclination and length of all development openings and drill holes, and points where openings are or will be within 8 m (25 ft) of a breakthrough.
If an active heading is within 8 m (25 ft) of another underground opening or drill hole, the underground working supervisor must, before any round is fired,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a thorough examination of other underground openings, drill hole collars, or the nearest point of intersection,
ensure that the heading can be safely advanced, and
ensure that access to the nearest point of intersection with the other opening or drill hole is guarded.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The underground working supervisor must ensure that all findings, and any corrective actions taken, under subsection (2) are documented in the Underground Record referred to in section 22.7.

If 2 headings are expected to connect and are within 8 m (25 ft) of connecting, all work must cease in one of the headings, and all previously blasted holes must be examined for remnants of explosives.

bcl:section.bcl:text: When workers are working at adjacent underground work sites, they must agree to mutually acceptable blasting times and procedures.

The employer must ensure that an underground working is not abandoned, nor work discontinued, until material broken in the last round has been cleared from the face of the heading, and the face examined for holes or sockets containing explosives.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The transport of explosives from the magazine or other surface storage place must be arranged so that no undue delay will occur between the time the explosives leave the surface storage and the time they are properly stored or used underground.
Detonators transported on a shaft conveyance must be transported separately from other explosives and materials.
The hoist operator must be notified before explosives are moved on a shaft conveyance.
Safety staging must be rigged inside the sinking bucket at a depth of 107 cm (42 in) from the rim, to ensure safe handling of the explosives.
When explosives are transported in underground workings by means of tracked or trackless mechanical haulage,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the speed of the vehicle must not at any time exceed 6 km/h (4 mph),
definite arrangements for the right of way of a vehicle carrying explosives must be made before the vehicle is moved,
the explosives must be protected from trolley wires, batteries or other hazards,
the vehicle must have a flashing light and reflective signs conspicuously displaying the word "EXPLOSIVES" not less than 15 cm (6 in) in height, and
the vehicle engine must be shut off while loading or unloading explosives, except when needed to operate a power takeoff.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Explosives must be placed in separate, suitable locked containers, or a single container where they are separated by a barrier approved under the Explosives Act (Canada).
If mechanical track haulage is used the locomotive must pull the conveyance carrying explosives as close to the point of use as possible.
When explosives are being transported by track haulage they must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 207/2021, App. A, s. 70 (b).]
be protected from trolley wires, batteries, or other hazards, and
not be carried on the locomotive.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Explosives must not be stored underground without the prior approval of the Board.

A day box in an underground working must be located in a safe stabilized area where there is no possibility of being struck by a train or mobile equipment, at least 60 m (200 ft) from any shaft, hoist room, portal, refuge station or worker assembly area, transformer vault, or combustible refuse.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 207/2021, App. A, s. 71 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. J, s. 6.]
Precautions must be taken to ensure that neither heated materials nor electrical equipment come into direct contact with explosives.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Explosives used in underground workings must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: possess a Fume Class 1 rating as established by the Explosives Branch of the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources (Canada), and
have prior written approval for use from the Board if not of a Fume Class 1 rating.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The blasting line must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meet the requirements of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M421-93, Use of Electricity in Mines,
be readily identifiable as blasting cable,
be suspended from insulated supports, and
not be located in close proximity to any electrical lighting or power line.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Where a safe means of exit can not be guaranteed, such as in a shaft or raise, a remote means of initiation must be used.
An effective water spray (atomizer) must be activated in every development heading at the time of the blast.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Written procedures for atmospheric testing and return to the blast site must be developed for each underground working.
Workers must be trained in the procedures and copies must be readily available to all workers for reference.
After a blast is detonated, workers must not return to the blast site until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a minimum of 10 minutes has elapsed, and

tests have confirmed that the concentrations of carbon monoxide or nitrogen dioxide do not exceed the exposure limits prescribed in this Regulation, the oxygen level is not less than 19.5%, and the concentrations of flammable substances are under 20% of their lower explosive limit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Testing must be carried out cautiously by a qualified person, following established safe work procedures which will prevent exposure to levels above exposure limits.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Before other work can take place in a blast site,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all hazards must be identified and controlled,
adequate dust suppression controls must be in place before mucking, and
loose material must be scaled, trimmed or otherwise stabilized by the use of equipment, machines, and methods which minimize the danger of injury to workers.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No safety fuse assembly in underground working
bcl:section.bcl:text: A safety fuse assembly must not be used in an underground working.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Mechanical excavating devices, such as tunnel boring machines and road headers, must have an effective dust control and ventilation system which maintains workers' exposure to dust below the applicable exposure limits in this Regulation.
Such systems must be maintained in good working order and must be operational whenever the mechanical excavating device is working.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Before any work is done in the confined area at the head of a tunnel boring machine, the machine head must be retracted a full piston stroke from the face, if possible.
Elevated work in connection with mechanical excavating equipment must be carried out using suitable work platforms.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Fixed and Mobile Equipment in Underground Working

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An inspection and maintenance log must be provided and maintained for each unit of mobile equipment used underground.
The operator of any equipment must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: examine the equipment before using it,
note any deficiencies in the vehicle log, and

not operate the equipment until repairs have been made by a qualified person, and noted in the log, or a qualified person has provided assurance that it is safe to operate the equipment, and has noted the reason in the log.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If no deficiencies or unsafe conditions are found, this must be noted in the log.

Before operating equipment the operator must read the most recent entries in the log and if an unsafe condition has been recorded but not corrected the equipment must not be used until repairs have been made by a qualified person, or assurance is given that the equipment is not unsafe to operate and the reason noted in the log.
The employer must monitor the log system to ensure that it is effective.
Records must be kept in the log for all unsafe conditions reported and repairs effected to correct them.
Each entry in the log must show the time and date of the entry and the name of the worker who made the entry.
Only diesel fueled internal combustion engines may be used underground.
Before using a diesel engine underground the employer must first obtain permission from the Board.

Diesel fuel for use underground must meet the requirements of CGSB Standard CAN/CGSB-3.16-M88 Mining Diesel Fuel, but flash point restrictions may be relaxed in accordance with the supplier's recommendations for cold weather conditions.
All diesel fueled equipment used underground must be equipped with adequate devices to control exhaust emissions.
If diesel fueled equipment used underground is fitted with an exhaust scrubber it must be of a type acceptable to the Board.

All diesel powered mobile equipment used underground, capable of holding more than 25 litres (5.5 imp gal) of combustible fluids, must be fitted with a multinozzle fire suppression system in accordance with CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M424.2-M90, Non-Rail-Bound Diesel-Powered Machines for Use in Non-Gassy Underground Mines, which operates automatically in the event of a fire.

It must be possible to manually activate the fire suppression system by means of easily accessible ground level devices from the operator's station and from each side of the machine, and the activation of the system must cause engine shutdown.
If, in the opinion of the Board, sufficient danger is present, the employer must use fire-resistant fluids in diesel powered equipment.

Hoses and lines ducting flammable or combustible liquid on mobile equipment used underground must be installed in accordance with CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M424.2-M90, Non-Rail-Bound Diesel-Powered Machines for Use in Non-Gassy Underground Mines.
Such hoses and lines must be shielded to prevent leaks or spills from contacting hot surfaces or other ignition sources.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Any diesel engine being operated in an underground working must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not expose workers to respirable combustible dust (RCD) from the exhaust in excess of 1.5 mg/m3 based on an 8-hour time weighted exposure, and
not idle unnecessarily.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 46 (c).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that a written traffic control scheme is developed for the underground working which provides that where a worker or workers are working in proximity to track or mobile equipment, both the workers and the equipment operators are fully aware of each others' presence.
If an equipment operator encounters pedestrian traffic at a location other than a safety station, the operator must stop and only proceed when the pedestrian gives permission to do so.
The employer must ensure that a clear space is provided in an underground working for safely passing workers or equipment which provides

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for track haulage, at least 60 cm (2 ft) clear space on one side of the tracks, free of tripping and slipping hazards, and
for trackless haulage, at least 2 m (6.5 ft) total clear space, free of tripping and slipping hazards.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minimum clear space cannot be maintained, safety stations must be excavated at least every 30 m (100 ft) to provide an avoidance space for workers.
The safety stations must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: clearly identified and marked,
clean and free of obstructions,
cut as close to perpendicular to the haulage way as is practicable,
at least 1 m (39 in) deep, in addition to the clearance from the vehicle to the wall,
at least 2 m (6.5 ft) high and at least 1.5 m (5 ft) wide, and
excavated on the same side of the haulage way if more than one safety station is required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Safety stations are not required if the traffic control system prevents simultaneous movement of pedestrians and machinery.
The employer must ensure that a locomotive is equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a hold-to-run type of control,
properly maintained headlights, front and rear,
an audible warning system, which must be operated whenever the locomotive is about to move, and to warn workers if they may be endangered by movement of the locomotive,
safe seating for the operator,
an effective braking system, with a parking brake,
non-slip material on steps and footboards,
handholds for entering or leaving the operator's station, and
a restraining device or door if there is a hazard to workers of falling.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that haulage equipment has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a safety chain or other suitable restraining device between all haulage units,
a positive locking device on rocker type cars to prevent accidental dumping, and
a reflector and a suitable beam or flashing light to indicate the rear of the train.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that any track mucking equipment is provided with an operator's foot stand which is maintained in position and used when the mucking machine is being operated.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Workers must not pass

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: between the cars of haulage equipment at any time, or
any haulage equipment that is being loaded during mucking operations unless the loading machine has finished loading the car or stopped mucking, and the operator has given permission to proceed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must establish and workers must follow safe work procedures for switching cars.
Fly switching is prohibited.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that derailed equipment is rerailed by means of jacks or other mechanical devices designed for this purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operator of a locomotive must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the train is pulled rather than pushed, unless impracticable,
nothing is placed on top of the locomotive unless it is adequately secured, does not extend beyond the ends or sides, nor into the cab of the locomotive, and does not obscure the operator's view,
the brake is applied, the operating control is in neutral and the main switch is in the non-operating position if the locomotive is unattended, and
the locomotive is operated from within the operator's position.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the operator's vision is limited when pushing muck cars or other equipment, the train must not be moved until a signal worker has been stationed in a safe position at the head of the train with an effective means of communication with the operator.
If locomotives are to be operated by an automatic system or by remote control, prior written acceptance must be obtained from the Board.
Rail tracks in use must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be maintained in safe condition,
have joints and fish plates installed directly over the ties,
be maintained reasonably level and free of bumps, dips and obstructions, and
have drainage that prevents water from covering the rails.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A rail switch in which a worker's foot may be trapped must have guards at the frog, guard rail, and switch point.
The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: portable switches are covered between the rails, and
switches on the main haulage line are equipped with suitable safety devices and maintained to allow the free flow of haulage equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If trackless loading and hauling equipment is to be operated by an automatic system or by remote control, prior written acceptance must be obtained from the Board.
If operated by an automatic system or remote control, loading and hauling equipment must be designed so that in the event of failure of the control system the equipment will immediately stop.
Every unit of equipment that is automatically or remotely controlled must be controlled independently of any other unit of equipment so there is no interference between one unit and another.
Operators of automatic or remote control equipment must be positioned in a safe area clear of the equipment's range of motion.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that automatic or remote control equipment is fitted with lights which indicate the width of the vehicle.
The employer must ensure that haulage roads are free of holes, ruts, excessive water and loose rock, and are maintained in safe operating condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that waste dumps or spoil areas

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are provided with a safe means of entry and exit,
are adequately illuminated,
are operated in accordance with written safe work procedures, and
have effective controls to prevent erosion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A dump or stockpile area must be examined daily by a qualified person who must communicate any dangerous or abnormal conditions to affected workers.
The employer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appoint only qualified and suitably equipped persons as dump workers,

where material is to be dumped from a vehicle into a bin, raise, shaft or other opening, provide and maintain a barrier capable of preventing a vehicle from inadvertently entering the bin, raise or opening, and
where dumping is not allowed or dangerous, prevent dumping by barricading the entrance sufficiently to prevent access and posting a sign which reads "No Entry for Dumping Purposes".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Operators are prohibited from dumping material from a haulage vehicle

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: over a bank more than 3 m (10 ft) high, or

within 3 m (10 ft) of the dump berm crest if the bank is more than 3 m (10 ft) high, except when dumping into a bin, raise, or other opening and a dump berm is in place and a dump worker is directing vehicles to the dumping position.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The driver of a haulage truck must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: where the bank is more than 3 m (10 ft) high and the dumping position is within 3 m of the dump berm crest, move the vehicle backward to the dumping position, nor begin dumping before having received verbal directions or standard visual signals as shown in Figure 22-1,
operate the vehicle in reverse for a distance greater than 4 truck lengths on

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a dump, or
a stockpile, ramp, road, or a ramp or road that is under construction, unless the ramp or road has a positive gradient of more than 5%.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A qualified and suitably equipped person, who is responsible for directing traffic at a dump point, must inspect the condition of the dump site as required and report any dangerous or abnormal condition to a supervisor so that corrective action can be taken.
A track waste dump must be equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: guardrails and toeboards, meeting the requirements of Part 4 (General Conditions), on all walkways on an elevated dump,
a securely anchored stop block at the end of the dump track capable of stopping a fully loaded train, and
a device to prevent haulage cars from overturning or kicking back when dumping.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If an electrical trolley system is used in dumping operations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: equipment must be arranged to prevent inadvertent contact with energized lines, and
all affected workers must be instructed in appropriate safe work procedures.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Figure 22-1: Standard hand signals for controlling mobile equipment movement
Figure 22-1 (continued): Standard hand signals for controlling mobile equipment movement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: where a timber work platform is used, the main platform bearers are securely pinned to prevent them from dislodging,
ladderways and travelways used for foot traffic are maintained in good repair and clean condition,

a raise in excess of 50 measured from horizontal and 15 m (50 ft) in length has separate compartments for the passage of workers and blasted material during the driving operation and, where timber is used, that it is installed to within 5 m (16 ft) of the face, and

if an accessway and a skipway occupy the same compartment in a raise, the accessway is not used by workers when the skip is in motion, and a guard is installed between the accessway and skipway to prevent workers from falling into the skipway.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The requirements of subsection (1) do not apply to a raise using mechanical raise equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Guarding the bottom of the raise
bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if work is being performed in a raise, the bottom of the raise is effectively guarded to protect workers from falling objects, by a barrier and sign reading "Danger Workers Working Above",
the top end of pilot holes are effectively guarded, and
if a raise is within 2 rounds of breaking through to surface or another work area, a worker is guarding the area of breakthrough.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that explosives are not taken up the raise until all holes are drilled and are ready for loading.
The employer must ensure that a suspended drill platform

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complies with the requirements in Part 13 (Ladders, Scaffolds and Temporary Work Platforms) for suspended work platforms,
is stabilized to prevent lateral sway or spinning while in the work position,
is provided with a protective canopy that fully covers the work platform during the first access following a blast, and provides protection for workers if a section is left open for work purposes,
has an effective means of two-way communication between the hoist operator and the work platform, and the communication line is protected from damage,
is provided with a safe means of emergency escape, and
is examined at the beginning of each shift, and has any defects corrected before use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a raise climber is installed, the Board must be notified and, if required, the employer must submit the design drawings and technical details of the installation, including construction materials, rated load capacities, dimensions, operating controls and safety features.
The materials and procedures used in the construction of a raise climber must conform to the requirements of appropriate standards of the CSA or ASTM.

A raise climber must not be put into service unless a certificate is available from the manufacturer, or a professional engineer, attesting that all critical load bearing components of the complete assembly and its accessories have been inspected and non-destructively tested by approved methods.

At least once a year after it has been put into service, or when ordered by the Board, any part of a raise climber installation which if it failed could endanger workers must be non-destructively tested by persons certified in accordance with CGSB Standard CAN/CGSB-48.9712-95, Qualification and Certification of Non-destructive Testing Personnel, and a copy of the test report must be made available on site for inspection by an officer.

A raise climber that has previously been in use in any place beyond the control of the present employer must not be re-installed until the inspections and tests required by subsection (3) have been carried out.

bcl:section.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Regs. 312/2003, App. A, ss. 5 and 25.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every raise climber must have a durable and legible identification plate which shows

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the manufacturer's name, the date of manufacture, the model number and serial number, and
the maximum allowable speed and maximum allowable load ratings as certified by the manufacturer or a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Raise climbers must be equipped with at least 2 separate and independently operated service brakes, each capable of safely stopping and holding the conveyance under all rated conditions of load and speed.
An automatic overspeed brake which is capable of bringing the conveyance to a safe stop under any rated load condition from a predetermined overspeed must be installed.
Each brake or braking system must be capable of being independently tested.
If electromechanical brakes are installed they must be activated immediately should the power supply to the climber be interrupted.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An electrically powered raise climber must have at least one service brake which automatically applies in the event of an interruption of the power supply to the climber, and in such an event, the service brake must be capable of being

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operated manually by workers in the climber to lower it safely under continuous control, and
released manually, provided that another brake is available for workers in the climber to lower it to safety under continuous control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Raise climber brakes must either be designed to compensate automatically for lining wear, or the means for manual adjustment must be readily accessible.
Brake blocks and linings must be protected from water, oil, grease or other substances which could adversely affect them.
The design of the brake system must ensure that the failure of any one component will still leave sufficient braking capacity to bring the climber to a safe stop.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every raise climber must have all exposed gearing, chain drives, couplings, or any moving parts which could endanger workers effectively guarded or otherwise protected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All operating controls of a raise climber must be situated in a convenient position to allow for their safe operation.

An emergency switch must be provided in the cab of every electrically operated raise climber that will cut off the power to the drive motors if the main control contact fails to open, or in any other emergency.

All electrical equipment, including switches, connectors, wiring and cables must be designed, installed and weatherproofed to ensure the integrity of the electric components under all operating conditions.
An electrically powered raise climber must not be operated at a potential of more than 750 volts, and must be protected by a ground fault system.
The operating controls and electrical panels of an electrically driven raise climber must be capable of being locked out to prevent unauthorized operation.
Every raise climber must be equipped with a suitable fire extinguisher.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 420/2004, s. 11.]
Work platforms used during raise driving with a raise climber operating at an inclination greater than 60 from the horizontal must be fitted with substantial covers.
Work platforms must be securely anchored to the raise climber guides or rails when being used by workers.
Before any work is done from a work platform all brakes must be applied and the safety device attached to the guide rail.

bcl:section.bcl:text: No more than one raise climber conveyance may be installed in a raise unless approved by the Board.
The static factor of safety of all load carrying components of raise climbers and associated equipment must be no less than 5 under the maximum rated load conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 47.]
Defective or damaged bolts must not be used and all exposed bolts and other components must be protected against damage from falling rock.
Only racks and pinions supplied by the manufacturer or certified by a professional engineer may be used.

All permanent raise climber installations used to transport workers must be fitted with a device to continuously monitor the integrity of the rack ahead of the driving pinions, or with a braking system which operates independently of the rack.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 48.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An effective means of communication must be provided between a raise climber conveyance and the base from which it operates.
If intermediate levels or landings are served by the conveyance, the Board may require the installation of a suitable signal system.

After a raise climber is installed and before it is put into service, the complete installation must be inspected and tested by authorized workers who have available to them the manufacturer's or professional engineer's manual which details specifications and test procedures.

A complete record of the inspection and tests required by subsection (1) and all other inspections and tests, defects, damage or problems, and repairs or maintenance done must be entered in a raise climber log, which must be maintained at the site, and made available for inspection by an officer.

All entries in the log must be dated and signed by the person who carried out the work, and the supervisor in charge of the installation must check and countersign the entries at least once each week.
Whenever a raise climber is operating, the end of the track on which it travels must be fitted with a stop block to prevent the conveyance from being taken beyond the end of the track.
All permanent electrically driven raise climber installations must be provided with devices which will automatically stop the conveyance at the upper and lower limits of travel.

The employer must appoint qualified persons to establish mechanical and electrical maintenance schedules for each raise climber, and to ensure that all maintenance is carried out in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and the requirements of this Regulation.
A mechanic must check an operating raise climber each day to ensure that it is operating safely.

At least once a week, a mechanic, and for an electrically driven raise climber, an electrician, must perform routine servicing in accordance with the manufacturer's requirements and this Regulation, and inspect and test all safety and protective devices to ensure that they are working properly.
Before recommencing operations after a prolonged shutdown, a full inspection of the complete installation must be made by authorized workers.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. F, s. 7.]
The operator of a raise climber must ensure that the brakes are in safe working condition at the beginning of the shift, and that the over speed brake is tested at least once a day.

Each day, before normal operations begin, the raise climber must be put through its full range of movements to ensure that all limit switches, brakes, controls, audio and visual indicators are functioning correctly.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a worker carrying out a prescribed inspection or test on a raise climber installation finds a defect, fault, malfunction or any other condition which could affect the safe operation of the equipment, the worker must immediately notify the supervisor in charge of the installation, and the raise climber must not be used until remedial action has been taken and the supervisor authorizes a resumption of use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 49.]

Repairs to a rack or pinion must only be carried out under the direction of a manufacturer's representative or a professional engineer, and the repaired components must be non-destructively tested in accordance with the requirements of section 22.110 (4).
Means must be readily available to enable workers to descend from a raise climber in the event of a power failure or other emergency.
The employer must ensure that operators of raise climbers and other workers who would be involved in the emergency descent of trapped workers are trained in the use of the emergency equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The supervisor in charge of a raise climber installation must ensure that the maximum load specified on the identification plate is never exceeded.
Except for inspection purposes workers are prohibited from riding on work platforms while they are in motion.
When ascending the raise following a blast, the operator must carefully monitor the condition of the guide rail and rack ahead of the conveyance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Equipment or materials being carried in a raise climber conveyance must be properly secured.
Only workers needed for the work to be done may be transported with explosives, steel, timber or similar material or equipment.
Material or equipment must not be dropped down a raise from the conveyance.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The electrical supply to an electrically driven raise climber must be disconnected during preparation for a blast.
The employer must ensure that a raise climber is thoroughly cleaned at least weekly.

Excavation of shafts and installation of hoists in an underground working must be in accordance with the applicable regulations from the Health, Safety and Reclamation Code for Mines in British Columbia or such other requirements as the Board may prescribe.
The employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the collar of a shaft is effectively stabilized, and
the top of a shaft or opening is effectively guarded to prevent workers or material from falling into the shaft.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that ladder ways, access ways, and platforms are maintained in a safe and clean condition and kept clear of the material hoist system.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. J, s. 7.]
Before a worker is permitted to enter a large diameter hole (LDH)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the hole must be adequately ventilated,
the hole must be tested for oxygen, flammable gases and other airborne contaminants, and
all in-hole electrical equipment must be grounded.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that, before a worker enters a vertical LDH,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the collar of the hole is stabilized,
a casing of adequate strength, extending at least 1 m (39 in) above the surface level, is installed,
the worker entering the hole wears a fall arrest harness attached to a securely anchored lifeline, tended by a worker equipped and capable of rendering immediate assistance, and
there is an effective communication system established between the hoist operator and the worker tending the lifeline.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Workers entering large diameter holes must not descend more than 3 m (10 ft) below the casing of the hole unless ground conditions have been inspected and certified safe in writing by a professional engineer, and copies of the certification must be maintained at the worksite.
If water may be encountered in the hole, the bottom of the work platform must be fitted with flotation devices capable of positively supporting the platform and its load.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. D, s. 22.]
Workers must not enter a horizontal LDH unless it has a casing of sufficient strength to hold the ground.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If an underground working is classified as gassy a written notice specifying the contaminant gas or vapour must be posted at a conspicuous location on the worksite.
Every worker in a gassy underground working must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: informed of the hazardous condition, and
instructed in the necessary precautions for the gassy condition.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In a gassy underground working additional testing for the naturally occurring gases must be conducted continuously

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at all faces, places of work and passageways,
at the equipment operator's station,
in the exhaust duct,
at a probe hole during drilling,
before loading explosives, and
before blasting loaded holes.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Continuous explosive gas monitors must be equipped with automatic alarm systems that are set and maintained to warn workers to evacuate at 20% of the lower explosive limit (LEL), or if the gas monitor malfunctions.
The main ventilation system must be on an independent electrical circuit and fans must be explosion proof and non-sparking.
If the ventilation system malfunctions

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every worker must leave the underground working, and
workers must not return until safe ventilation is restored, and the atmosphere tested and declared safe.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The air velocity in the main air duct must be measured at least once a day.
Workers are not permitted to smoke, or to carry or keep ignition material in an underground working if flammable gas is present.
For welding, burning or other spark producing operations, the employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a hot work permit is obtained,
the operations only take place in atmospheres containing less than 20% of the LEL of gases or vapours,
testing for gases or vapours is done before, and continuously during work, and
welding and burning operations are otherwise in compliance with this Regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Objects made of or containing aluminum, magnesium, titanium or light metal alloy are prohibited in a flammable gassy underground working, except for electrical equipment within a flameproof enclosure, or circumstances where there is no possibility of friction or impact.
An internal combustion engine used in a gassy underground working must be equipped with a flame arrester at the exhaust outlet.
If a mechanical excavator is used

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: automatic and manual gas monitoring equipment must be provided to test the atmosphere at the working face,
electrical power in the heading must be automatically shut off when 20% of the LEL of a gas or vapour is reached, and
a manual shut off control for the electric power in the heading must be provided at the working area, and the control must be immediately accessible to workers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a gassy underground working, or in a working containing combustible dusts in sufficient quantity to present a fire or explosion hazard, fire resistant fluids meeting the requirements of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M423-M87 Fire Resistant Hydraulic Fluids, category 1 or 2 must be used in hydraulic systems of more than 10 litre (2.2 imp gal) capacity on equipment in use underground.
Subsection (1) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: engine hydraulic valve lifters, hydraulic cooling fan drivers, lubricating systems, fuel injection systems, torque converters, transmissions, and axles, or
braking systems employing totally enclosed friction elements immersed in a liquid coolant, and to braking systems with hydraulics independent of any other hydraulic system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an underground working or portion of an underground working contains or has the potential to contain coal dust or other combustible dusts in quantities sufficient to present a fire/explosion hazard, the Board may require additional safety measures to be instituted.
Such measures must meet the requirements of the applicable sections of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 22 (a).]
CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M421-93, Use of Electricity in Mines, and
CSA Standard CAN/CSA-M424.1-88, Flameproof Non-Rail-Bound Diesel-Powered Machines for Use in Gassy Underground Coal Mines.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: derrick means a stationary or portable structure used to support the hoisting and lowering mechanism on a rig;
flow piping system means a temporary or portable system of piping and other component parts, including valves and fittings, that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: located above ground, and
for use to convey to or from a wellhead a liquid under pressure, or a gas under pressure, during drill stem testing, swabbing, cementing, well servicing or well stimulation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: hot work means work which involves burning, welding, riveting, grinding, using fire or spark producing tools, or other work that produces a source of ignition;
lower explosive limit means the minimum concentration of combustible gas or vapour in air, expressed as a percentage by volume, that will ignite if a source of ignition is present;
rig includes a derrick and all equipment that is directly involved with drilling or servicing a well;
well means an opening in the ground which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is made or being made by drilling, boring, or in any other manner

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for the purpose of obtaining oil, gas or crude bitumen or from which any oil, gas or crude bitumen is obtainable,
for the purpose of developing or using a reservoir for the storage of natural gas, or
for the purpose of obtaining geothermal energy,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is made or being made by drilling or boring for the purpose of obtaining water to inject into an underground formation,
is used, drilled or being drilled for the purpose of injecting gas, air, water, or other substance or a form of energy into an underground formation,
is an evaluation well,
is a test hole, or
is drilled or being drilled to a depth of more than 600 m (2 000 ft) to obtain geological or geophysical information.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the exploration for oil, gas, crude bitumen, or geothermal energy,
drilling, operating and servicing a well,
producing, distributing and refining oil, gas, crude bitumen or geothermal energy from a well, and
ancillary processes associated with paragraphs (a) to (c).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 23.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an activity involves the work of 2 or more employers or their workers, each employer must notify the owner, or the person engaged by the owner to be the prime contractor, in advance of any undertaking likely to create a hazard for a worker of another employer.
If a work location has overlapping or adjoining work activities of 2 or more employers that create a hazard to workers,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner, or if the owner engages another person to be the prime contractor, then that person, must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: appoint a qualified coordinator for the purpose of ensuring the coordination of health and safety activities for the location, and
provide up-to-date information as specified in subsection (4) readily available on site, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each employer must give the coordinator appointed under subsection (2) (a) (i) the name of a qualified person designated to be responsible for that employer's site health and safety activities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The duties of the qualified coordinator appointed under subsection (2) (a) (i) include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: informing employers and workers of the hazards created, and
ensuring that the hazards are addressed throughout the duration of the work activities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The information required by subsection (2) (a) (ii) includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the qualified coordinator appointed under subsection (2) (a) (i),
a site drawing, which must be posted, showing project layout, first aid location, emergency transportation provisions, and the evacuation marshalling station, and
a set of work procedures designed to protect the health and safety of workers at the workplace, developed in accordance with the requirements of this Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must identify the work activities or circumstances, including releases of gases, that have caused or may cause significant risk of injury or occupational disease to workers.

The employer must analyze the risks arising out of the work activities or circumstances identified under subsection (1) and implement safe work procedures if the activities or circumstances create a hazard.
The procedures implemented under subsection (2) must state the number of workers involved, the steps to be followed and the safety equipment required.
When flammable liquids or finely divided materials which may produce a dust which is flammable or explosive are being transferred between containers, the containers must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in firm contact with each other, and
continuously electrically bonded throughout the transfer to prevent accumulation of a static electric charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If tanks, mixers or processing vessels are used for flammable or explosive substances, they must be electrically bonded and grounded while the contents are being transferred.
A wellhead may be used as a ground

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for dissipating static electricity, and
if tested and proved acceptable, for an electrical distribution system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Smoking is prohibited on or about a rig, within 25 m (80 ft) of the well bore and within 25 m (80 ft) of any well, production facility or gas processing plant.
Open flames are prohibited within 25 m (80 ft) of the well bore whenever gas may be emitted from the well or any other source.
If iron sulfide is removed from a tank

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the iron sulfide must be kept wetted down until safely disposed of, and
other materials and equipment which are contaminated must be kept wetted down or kept in an inert atmosphere until cleaned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If regular monitoring and hotwork permits are not in use to control ignition sources

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: internal combustion engines must be shut down within the zone defined by the BC Electrical Code and the Drilling and Production Regulation as a Class 1 Division 2 or higher classification, unless their operation is integral to the work process, and

diesel engines required to operate within the zone defined by the BC Electrical Code and the Drilling and Production Regulation as a Class 1 Division 2 or higher classification must have a positive air shutoff or other effective method for engine shut down.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Mobile equipment powered by a diesel engine and used for maintenance or repair work on pressurized gathering, distribution and transmission equipment must have a positive air shutoff or other effective method of engine shut down.
Written safe work procedures must be implemented to ensure the safety of workers lighting or operating a flare tip, flare stack or flare line.
Workers must be instructed in the application of the written work procedures required by subsection (1).
Before workers enter a flare system danger area where the installation is temporary and remote ignition of the pilot is not feasible

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the flare line must be isolated, and
contaminants in the flare pit area must be less than 20% of the lower explosive limit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The location of a flare pit or stack must not interfere with safe access to the work area.
If feasible, there must be a continuous ignition source before flow to a flare pit or stack occurs.
Non-freezing fire extinguishers, other firefighting equipment and firefighting personnel must be provided as required by subsections (2), (3) and (4) and Table 23-1.
The minimum requirements for a twin agent unit are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 1 100 litres (250 imp gal) pre-mixed ATC foam solution at 6%,
680 kg (1 500 lbs) potassium bicarbonate dry chemical system,
30 m (100 ft) discharge hose, and
two firefighting personnel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minimum requirements for a continuous foam unit are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 475 litres (100 imp gal) ATC foam concentrate,
680 kg (1 500 lbs) potassium bicarbonate dry chemical system,
1 900 litres (400 imp gal) per minute centrifugal certified fire pump with one 65 mm (2.5 in) discharge port, two 38 mm (1.5 in) discharge ports, and one 125 mm (5 in) suction port, and
two firefighting personnel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Firefighting equipment must meet the requirements of NFPA 10, Portable Fire Extinguishers, 1990 Edition.

oasis:tcaption.oasis:line: Table 23-1: Minimum requirements for firefighting equipment

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Service truck of 1 tonne capacity or more
Continuous foam unit with 100 barrel water truck

5 or more fracturing tanks or greater than
40% methanol water fracturing

The fire hazard must be evaluated in accordance with current industry standards,
and firefighting equipment and personnel must be provided as determined
necessary by the evaluation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Alcohol must not be added to air lines at the air intake side of a compressor.
The air in the alcohol injection system must be bled down to atmospheric pressure before opening an air operating system to inject alcohol.

If an air operating system supplies air for breathing purposes, the alcohol injection system must be isolated, the system purged of old air, and air purifying systems placed between existing piping and workers using the breathing system.
Pipelines, piping systems, fittings and valves must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be designed, constructed and maintained to safely withstand the anticipated internal pressures and external loads,
be restrained from undue horizontal, vertical or swinging motion, and
if applicable, meet the requirements of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: CSA Standard Z662-94, Oil and Gas Pipeline Systems, or

API Recommended Practice 520, Sizing, Selection, and Installation of Pressure-Relieving Devices in Refineries, Part I — Sizing and Selection (July 1990, 5th Edition) and Part II — Installation (November 1988, 3rd Edition), or
API Recommended Practice 521, Guide for Pressure-relieving and Depressuring Systems, dated November, 1990 (3rd edition), or
American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Standard B31.3-1993, Chemical Plant and Petroleum Refinery Piping.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 24 (d).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When a valve is to be disassembled

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it must be depressurized, purged or otherwise made safe, and
written safe work procedures must be followed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Process control and power systems must be designed to operate on the gas being used.
Hoses and fittings must be of a design suitable for the type of service for which they are used.
Quick connect fittings must be identified or have hardware controls to ensure connection only to the correct service.
Quick connect fittings for breathing air service must be different from and not compatible for connection to any other service.
Temporary piping and hose systems for hazardous fluids must be effectively protected from damage.
A positive displacement pump and attachments must have valves, pipes and fittings capable of withstanding the pump's maximum working pressure.
A quick closing type valve must not be used on the discharge line of a positive displacement pump.
A positive displacement pump must be protected against freezing.
Except for a pumping wellhead, a pressure relief device must be installed on the discharge side of a positive displacement pump, but a valve must not be installed between them.
For a wellhead utilizing a down-hole positive displacement pump, the employer must implement measures to prevent the pump from causing pressures that exceed the pressure rating of the system.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2012, App. B, s. 1.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Pipe racks and tubs must be placed on a level and firm surface.
Pipe, tubular goods or similar round material must be prevented from accidentally rolling off a pipe rack.
Spacers must be used between the layers of pipe or other material on a pipe rack.
Pipes or tubular goods must be restrained from uncontrolled movement.
Deck pins used to restrain pipes must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be at least 45 cm (18 in) high, and extend beyond the centre line of the pipe closest to the pins, or
if the pipe is tiered, extend one pipe diameter above the pipe closest to the pins.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Deck pins are not required if specialized dunnage is used.
Pipes or tubular goods must be adequately secured before restraining devices are removed.

While pipe is being loaded, unloaded or transferred, workers must not be on top of an unsecured load, between the load and the pipe racks or tubs, or in any other area made hazardous by potential pipe movement.
When pipe is being transferred between pipe racks, catwalks, or trucks, temporary supports or skids must be constructed, placed and anchored so that they will support the load placed upon them.
When transferring drill collars, tubular goods or other similar materials which are not provided with shoulders, pick up subs or other appropriate pipe handling equipment must be used.
A nubbin must not be used to pick up drill collars, tubular goods or similar materials unless the nubbin is equipped with a wire rope safety line and swivel for attachment to the elevator bails.

A trailer used as a pipe rack during drilling, servicing or pipe salvaging must have a guard, along the full length of both sides of the trailer, designed and constructed to ensure that when a pipe is hoisted into the derrick, the lower end of the pipe will not roll off the trailer.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 258/2008, App. G, s. 2.]
Pipes must be loaded on or unloaded from a truck one layer at a time.
Clamps and wire rope safety lines or chains must be used to fasten the kelly hose at the standpipe end to the derrick and at the swivel end of the swivel housing.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 51.]
Shock hoses from pump to standpipe must be restrained by safety lines if they are subject to whipping.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that workers do not use friction catheads after April 14, 1999.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The driver of a vehicle used for rigging up or tearing out equipment must not move the vehicle until signalled to move by a qualified signaller.
The signaller must ensure that workers are clear of the path of the vehicle, load and load line.

To prevent materials or equipment from rolling or sliding off a truck or trailer during unloading operations, load tie down devices must not be removed until the lifting slings and hoist line have been attached to the equipment or material that may slide or roll off, and slack in the hoist line and rigging has been taken up.
A worker must not remain or ride on a load or part of a load being raised, lowered or moved.
The movement of a load being raised or lowered must be controlled by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tag line long enough to ensure that the worker controlling it cannot be struck by the load, or
where a helicopter is being used, by effective work procedures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not work, stand or pass

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under a suspended load,
between the winch mechanisms and a load being winched, or
in areas where the worker may be injured due to winch line or mechanism failure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 52.]
Winch mechanisms, lines, slings, hooks and fittings must be inspected thoroughly by the equipment operator

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before commencing work, and
at such intervals as the nature of the work may require.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A vehicle driver in the oil and gas industry must, before operating a vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating greater than 5 500 kg (12 000 lbs.),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be certified in the applicable Energy Safety Canada driver training course acceptable to the Board, or
have completed driver training providing skills and knowledge for safe driving equivalent to or better than those required by paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 53.]
If material or equipment must be moved on steep terrain, a written plan must be prepared before snubbing or yo-yo operations are carried out.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Roads, bridges and other structures forming part of the road system used by mobile equipment to transport workers, equipment or materials in connection with operations covered by this Part must meet the requirements for roads and road maintenance in Part 26 (Forestry Operations and Similar Activities).
Liquids must be transported in properly designed and constructed tanks or vessels.

A tank which contains or may contain a fluid with hydrogen sulfide as a component must have an external means of gauging its contents, or if manual gauging or sampling is required, the worker doing the gauging or sampling must use a supplied air respirator meeting the requirements of Part 8 (Personal Protective Clothing and Equipment) for use in an IDLH atmosphere, and must be visually monitored by another worker equipped with an equivalent respirator and capable of effecting a rescue of the worker doing the gauging or sampling.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Liquefied gas used for purging or gauging operations or well stimulation
bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that workers are protected from hazards that may be caused by the release of liquefied gas being used for purging or gauging operations or well stimulation.
The drill mast must be lowered if equipment is being moved and there is a danger of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mast contacting power lines or other overhead obstructions, or
the unit losing stability.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seismic drill must have an emergency engine stopping device which is clearly identified, within reach of the drill operator at the drilling position, and tested daily.
Two workers must be present on the same shot hole while drilling.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a worker rides on a seismic line truck to perform work, there must be an effective means of communication between the driver and the worker.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 258/2008, App. G, s. 4.]
The owner must ensure that the work area is sized, constructed and laid out so that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the required equipment may be safely moved and operated, and
emergency response activities may be carried out.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. C, s. 8 (c).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each drilling and service rig must be inspected and repaired in accordance with the following applicable standards published by the Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors:

bcl:text.in:em: Recommended Practice 1.0, for Drilling Rigs, Mast Inspection and Certification, January 1, 1994;
Recommended Practice 2.0, for Drilling Rigs, Overhead Equipment Inspection and Certification, January 1, 1994;
Recommended Practice 3.0, for Service Rigs, Inspection and Certification of Masts, January 1, 1994;
Recommended Practice 4.0, for Service Rigs, Overhead Equipment Inspection and Certification, January 1, 1994;
Recommended Practice 1.0A, Addendum for Drilling Rigs, Substructure Inspection and Certification, September 12, 1995.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Inspections and repairs must be recorded in a Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors log book or equivalent log acceptable to the Board.
The log must be available on site for review by an officer.
The raising and lowering of a derrick must be done under the direct supervision of the rig manager or other qualified person.
When hoisting a mast section, rigging must be attached to designated lifting points only.
Lifting points must be clearly marked on each mast section of the derrick.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A master list of the weight of rig components must be kept on site.
Except for the operator at the controls, workers are prohibited from being on, in or beneath a derrick being raised, lowered or telescoped.

On each drilling and service rig there must be a minimum of 4 self-contained breathing apparatus in good working order, 2 together in each of 2 separate opposite locations, so that 2 apparatus are always accessible regardless of wind direction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When installing a blowout preventer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the preventer must be effectively restrained while it is being aligned, and
workers are prohibited from being located where they may be injured if the preventer swings or drops.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When removing a blowout preventer, 2 opposing anchor lines must remain in position until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the lifting sling is attached to the preventer,
the slack in the hoisting line and rigging is taken up, and
the draw works brake handle is tied down.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Spudding in must not start until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all guards are in place,
all platforms, stairways and handrails are installed and securely fastened,
the escape line, anchors and safety buggy are installed and inspected, and
all connecting pins are secured against dislodgment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A drilling or service derrick must have an emergency means of escape from the racking board that complies with section 23.39.2 or 23.39.3.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A drilling or service derrick must have a specially rigged and securely anchored line as an emergency means of escape that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provides a ready means of escape from the racking board,
consists of a wire rope not less than 13 mm (1/2 in) diameter,
has a length twice the vertical distance between the ground and the point at which it is attached to the derrick,
is effectively anchored and able to withstand a load of 13.3 kN (3 000 lbs), and
is kept free of obstructions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Equipment must not be placed, and vehicles must not pass, under the last 15 m (50 ft) of the escape line.
A safety buggy of a design acceptable to the Board must be installed and operated on the escape line.
The safety buggy required under subsection (3) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: kept at the racking board,
provided with an effective brake and means to prevent the trolley from coming off the escape line, and
inspected by a qualified person at least once a week.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The escape line must be tensioned so that a person seated in the safety buggy will touch the ground at a safe distance from the derrick, not less than 6 m (20 ft) from the ground level anchor.
A drilling or service derrick must have an emergency means of escape that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is available for use at the racking board whenever a person is working at that level during drilling or well servicing operations,
is able to simultaneously and safely transport all persons from the racking board level, either individually or as a group, to a location at ground level removed from the source of danger,
shields the persons using the system from any danger coming from the well bore during the descent or separates the persons using the system from such danger during the descent,
has a means to keep the persons using the system from falling out of or off of the emergency means of escape during descent, and
has a means, either automatic or manually controlled, to control the rate of descent to a speed that minimizes the risk of injury to the persons using the system when they near ground level.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The placement of equipment and the movement of vehicles in the area under the emergency means of escape required under subsection (1) must be controlled so as to ensure the emergency means of escape can be safely used.
The emergency means of escape required under subsection (1) must be inspected and tested in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each time the derrick is erected, before a person works at the racking board during drilling or well servicing operations, and
at least once each month when the rig is being used for drilling or well servicing operations and a person is working at the racking board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each person assigned to work at the racking board during drilling or well servicing operations must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have demonstrated proficiency in the use of the type of emergency escape system installed on the rig, and
participate in drills and receive retraining as necessary to ensure ongoing proficiency in the use of the escape system installed on the rig.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If dual purpose controls are used for automatic catheads, a locking device must be installed to prevent one cathead from being accidentally engaged while the other is operating.
The function of each draw works control must be clearly identified.
If a control may become engaged because of accidental contact with lines or other equipment, the control must be suitably guarded.
A stabbing board must be used by a worker located above the derrick floor during the running of casing or tubing, or well servicing operations.
A wooden stabbing board must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be fitted with expanded metal or wire rope fastened to the underside and along the full length of the board,
have each end of the board secured to the derrick by a wire rope of not less than 13 mm (1/2 in) diameter, or chain of at least equivalent strength, and
be at least 30 cm (12 in) wide.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A metal platform of equal width and strength may be used in place of a wooden stabbing board.
At the stabbing board, a personal fall protection system must be attached to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wire rope with a breaking strength of not less than 40 kN (9 000 lbs) stretched across the derrick at a location approximately 2 m (7 ft) above the stabbing board,
a cross-member of the derrick structure at a point approximately 2 m (7 ft) above the stabbing board, or
a solid support secured across the derrick at a location approximately 2 m (7 ft) above the stabbing board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Engine rooms, pump houses, derrick floors and derrickhand platforms must be enclosed to a sufficient height to provide protection against the weather.
When erecting, maintaining or dismantling derrick enclosures

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: safe work procedures must be implemented, and
where practicable, a safe work platform must be provided.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Workers are prohibited from straddling or climbing onto prefabricated wall panels during erection, maintenance or dismantling of derrick enclosures.
Safe exits must be provided directly to the outside on each of at least 3 sides of the derrick floor enclosure.
The pump house enclosure must have at least 2 doors, opening in different directions to the outside.
Exit doors of a derrick enclosure and the doors of the doghouse must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: open outward from the derrick floor, and
