bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, work area includes any area in which any forestry work is done but does not include the travelled portion of a road unless that portion of the road is being used as a landing.
Work in a work area in a forestry operation must be planned and the work area must be located, constructed, maintained and operated to ensure the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: logs can be moved safely in the area;
log piles and equipment used to handle the logs do not become unstable or otherwise create a hazard;
workers are able to work in locations clear of moving logs and equipment;
workers are not exposed to incoming or runaway logs or other debris;
the area is kept free from buildup of bark and other debris to the extent that it would pose a risk to workers;
an effective method of dust control is used and maintained.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Log piles must, to the extent practicable, be located on stable and relatively level ground.
Log piles must not be higher than the safe operating reach of equipment being used to handle the logs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log must not be passed over any worker or occupied vehicle or equipment.
Despite subsection (1), a log may be passed over a vehicle or equipment that is being loaded, if the log

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not pass over any portion of the vehicle or equipment that is occupied by a person, and
does not constitute a hazard for the occupant of the vehicle or equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not stand or pass under a suspended log.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Effective means of communication must be used in a forestry operation to control vehicle movements in any location where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a loader operator is unable to see the loading operation, or
log transporters are moving at landings, load-out points, water dumps, dry land sorts or railway reloads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, for the purposes of subsection (1), audible signals are used as the means of communication, the signals must meet the requirements of section 26.34 and Table 26.2.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]
Only persons permitted by law or by the workplace safe work procedures may be at landings, load-out points, water dumps, dry land sorts and railway reloads.

Bunk and stake assemblies, installed at a dry land sort for bundling logs, must have fixed stakes or be used with safe work procedures which ensure that no worker goes into the hazard area adjacent to or below self-tripping stakes unless the stakes are secured from releasing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cab guard means a barrier guarding the back of the cab of a log transporter;
certified welding inspector means a person who is certified as a Level 2 or Level 3 welding inspector in accordance with CSA Standard W178.2-08 (R2013), Certification of Welding Inspectors;

rated capacity, in relation to a cab guard, means the maximum cargo weight that may be transported by the log transporter and shift and contact the cab guard such that the cab guard is capable of withstanding a horizontal forward static load equal to 40% of that cargo weight, with this load uniformly distributed over the entire cab guard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the protection of the driver of a log transporter, the log transporter must have a cab guard that meets all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (3), the cab guard is at least 15 cm (6 in) higher than the cab;
the cab guard is at least as wide as the cab;
the cab guard has no opening large enough to permit any item of cargo to pass through it;
the cab guard is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: constructed with a main supporting structure made of steel, or

certified by a professional engineer as having a main supporting structure designed and constructed so that vibration and distortion generated by use of the log transporter cannot damage the cab guard;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is installed in a manner that ensures that the rated capacity of the cab guard is not diminished.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The cab guard of a self-loading log transporter may be less than the height specified in subsection (2) (a) but must not be less than the cab height.
The weight of cargo that is being transported by a log transporter and that may shift and contact the cab guard must not exceed the rated capacity of the cab guard.
The operator of a log transporter must record the results of the inspection, made before the start of operation on the shift, of the cab guard of the log transporter.
A log transporter must be removed from service if there are any cracks, damage or other conditions that will decrease the rated capacity of the cab guard of the log transporter.
A log transporter removed from service under subsection (6) must not be returned to service until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: repaired, and
inspected and certified to meet the rated capacity by the manufacturer, a professional engineer or a certified welding inspector, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is replaced by a cab guard that meets the requirements of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The cab guard of a log transporter must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permanently marked with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the name and address of its manufacturer,
the model number or serial number of the cab guard, and
the rated capacity of the cab guard, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identified by carrying in the log transporter a copy of a letter that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: accurately describes the cab guard,
certifies the model number or serial number of the cab guard and the rated capacity of the cab guard, and
has been signed by the manufacturer or a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log transporter carrying a log load must be equipped with bunks and stakes of adequate design and construction to safely perform their intended function.
Bunks must be able to rotate freely upon their pivots, if designed to do so.
Stakes, extensions and stake cables must be installed and maintained to ensure that when the log transporter is loaded

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the angle between the bunks and stakes at the base does not exceed 90, and
the angle between the bunks and the stakes and extensions above the base does not exceed the angle at which the stakes and extensions can safely withstand the maximum anticipated loads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Stakes must be constructed so that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: they can be released only from the opposite end of the bunk,
keeper pins are secured against unintended release, and
if they are over 1.2 m (4 ft) in height, springs or other mechanical means are fitted to facilitate their returning to a vertical position.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not go on bunks and trailer assemblies to raise or lower stakes and extensions unless it is impracticable to do otherwise.
If a worker must go on a bunk or trailer assembly to collapse stakes or extensions, the worker must be provided a safe means of getting on and off the bunk or trailer assembly.
Procedures must be developed and implemented for collapsing stakes or extensions during adverse weather conditions.
Stake extensions must be secured against inadvertent detachment from the stakes.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 39 (c).]
Stake cables must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not be made from swaged wire rope, and
conform to the following specifications.

oasis:entry.oasis:line: ≥ 2.6 m (8 ft 6 in) and ≤ 2.9 m (9 ft 6 in)
> 2.9 m (9 ft 6 in) and ≤ 3.7 m (12 ft)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Stake and bunk assemblies must be inspected daily, and must not be used if they show signs of excessive wear.
A record of all inspections conducted under subsection (8) must be maintained.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 39 (e).]
If logs are being loaded on a log transporter,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there must be an effective means of communication between the transporter operator and any workers involved in the loading, and
each worker involved in or in the vicinity of the loading must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: be in a safe location, and
without limiting subparagraph (i),

bcl:clause.bcl:text: be clear of any moving logs or logs that might move or fall,
not be standing on the cab of a truck or between the cab of the truck and a log being loaded, and
not be resting any part of the worker's body on a log.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log load on a log transporter must meet the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the log load and the log transporter

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are stable, without the use of wrappers or tiedowns, during loading and prior to transportation, and
will remain stable, after the log load is secured in accordance with section 26.68, during transportation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the log load does not impair the free and full movement of the log transporter;
the working load limits of stakes and stake cables are not exceeded;
to ensure that stakes remain at a safe angle, the bottom layer of logs is laid tight and arranged to minimize slack in the stake cables;
the bottom layer and side rows of the log load extend horizontally beyond at least 2 sets of stakes

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least 30 cm (11.8 in) on compensating-reach-type trailers, or
at least 15 cm (5.9 in) on other types of log transporters;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a log whose length is shorter than the distance between the stakes is not loaded above the top of the stakes unless the log is in a secure position;
the horizontal centreline of the top log in a side row that is immediately adjacent to a stake is not higher than the top of the stake;
if wrappers or tiedowns are used to secure a log stack of 3 or more layers, the top of the log stack is curved so that the middle part of the curve is higher than the sides of the curve;
the length of each log does not exceed the design limitations of a highway or other surface that the log transporter travels on;
the log load does not include limbs that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pose a risk of injury to a person, or
impair the safe operation of the log transporter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a log load must be secured in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this section, and
whichever of the following sections applies:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 26.68.1 [highways and mixed transportation routes];
section 26.68.2 [entirely off-highway transportation routes].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log transporter carrying a log load that is not yet secured as required by subsection (1) may be moved within a loading area if no person is exposed to the risk of logs, log chunks or debris falling off the log transporter.
If a log load is secured on a log transporter using wrappers or tiedowns, the following requirements must be met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the wrappers and tiedowns must be installed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the loading area or at a location that is close to the loading area,
as soon as practicable after the log load is loaded on the log transporter and, if the log transporter is a trailer, before the trailer is connected to a truck, and
so that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the log load is secure and no logs, log chunks or debris will fall off the log transporter while the log load is being transported,
the wrappers and tiedowns can be safely removed while load restraining equipment is in position,
no working load limit of a wrapper or tiedown is exceeded and each anchor point for a tiedown has at least the working load limit of the tiedown, and
each tiedown is located within 60 cm (23.6 in) horizontally from a bunk, flatdeck or other load supporting surface;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during transportation, the wrappers and tiedowns must be checked and kept tight;
logs in the log load must not be shifted or moved while the wrappers and tiedowns are installed or adjusted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tiedown must not be used to secure a log load on a log transporter unless the tiedown is marked with its working load limit.
Subject to subsection (6), bundle straps and banding must not be used to secure a log load on a log transporter.
Bundle straps and banding may be used to secure a log load on a log transporter in a loading area if no person is exposed to the risk of logs, log chunks or debris falling off the log transporter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Securing log loads — highways and mixed transportation routes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to the transportation of a log load if all or part of the transportation route, other than a crossing, is a highway.

A log load must be secured in accordance with the federal cargo securement standard and, for the purposes of this section, a reference in the standard to a highway is to be read as a reference to any road.
Section 2.3 [conflict with code or standard] does not apply in relation to the federal cargo securement standard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Securing log loads — entirely off-highway transportation routes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to the transportation of a log load if no part of the transportation route, other than a crossing, is a highway.
A log load must be secured on a log transporter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by installing, on each log stack and on any logs that are not part of a log stack, the following number of wrappers or tiedowns that conform to subsection (3):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the longest log that is to be secured by the wrappers or tiedowns is no more than 10.7 m (35 ft) long, at least 2 wrappers or tiedowns, each of which has a working load limit of at least 8.9 kN (2 000 lbf);

if the longest log that is to be secured by the wrappers or tiedowns is more than 10.7 m (35 ft) long, at least 3 wrappers or tiedowns, each of which has a working load limit of at least 13.3 kN (3 000 lbf), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without the use of wrappers or tiedowns by loading the logs

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: lengthwise with the horizontal centrelines of all of the logs below the top of the stakes on the log transporter, and
in accordance with the requirements set out in a current risk assessment that conforms to subsection (4) for the log hauling operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A wrapper or tiedown installed for the purposes of subsection (2) (a) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a safety factor of at least the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if wire rope, 4;
if polyester rope, 7;
if any other synthetic rope, 12;
if synthetic webbing, 3;
if chain, 4, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if chain, have a grade of at least 70.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (b), a risk assessment for a log hauling operation must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
be prepared by a qualified person, based on the circumstances of the log hauling operation, including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the speeds of the log transporters used in the operation,
the type, design and condition of the surfaces that the log transporters will travel on, including their grades,
the weather, and
the log characteristics,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify requirements for the loading, transportation and unloading of logs, and

set out the opinion of the qualified person that no logs, log chunks or debris will fall off a log transporter during loading, transportation or unloading of logs if the specified requirements are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log load that is secured under subsection (2) (b) in reliance on a current risk assessment must be transported and unloaded in accordance with the requirements set out in that assessment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removing wrappers and tiedowns and releasing stakes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, removal station means a structure that is designed to protect a person from being struck by logs, log chunks or debris falling off a log transporter when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a wrapper or tiedown installed on a log load is removed, or
a stake securing logs on a log transporter is released.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following activities must be conducted in accordance with written safe work procedures prepared by a qualified person:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: removing a wrapper or tiedown installed on a log load;
releasing a stake securing logs on a log transporter;
using a removal station.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The written safe work procedures referred to in subsection (2) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: posted in a conspicuous location at any place where the activities referred to in that subsection take place and maintained in a legible condition, or
effectively communicated to the workers and supervisors who conduct those activities if it is not practicable to post the safe work procedures in a conspicuous location.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Wrappers and tiedowns must not be removed and stakes securing logs on a log transporter must not be released when a person is preparing to unload logs from a log transporter unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is using a removal station, or
the logs are otherwise restrained to prevent them from falling on the person who is removing the wrappers or tiedowns or releasing the stakes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Once a wrapper or tiedown has been removed from a log load, the log load must not be moved if any person is exposed to the risk of logs, log chunks or debris falling off the log transporter.
A removal station must not be used unless it is certified by a professional engineer as capable of performing its intended function.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 42.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operator of a log transporter must follow safe operating procedures.
Without limiting subsection (1), the operator referred to in subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not overtake another moving industrial vehicle, except on a signal from the other vehicle operator,
use extreme caution when approaching vehicles coming from the opposite direction,
keep a safe distance when following crew transportation vehicles, having due regard for road and grade conditions and visibility,
drive at a speed appropriate to the log transporter's capabilities, the road design and condition, the traffic, the visibility and the weather conditions, and
not operate the log transporter while impaired by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: fatigue, or
any other cause, substance or matter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that could prevent the operator from operating the log transporter safely.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, hauling cycle means the time allowed for each round trip.
The operator of a log transporter must maintain a daily log into which must be entered the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date of the entry;
the printed name of the operator;
the truck licence plate or unit number;
the odometer reading of the truck at the beginning of the day, if the truck has an odometer;
the name of each contractor or employer for whom the operator worked during the day;
the start and stop time of each trip the operator makes;
the distance driven for each trip the operator makes;
the total distance driven by the operator during the day;
the total driving hours during the day;
the hauling cycle.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A log transporter must be equipped with a horn or whistle which, under normal conditions,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is distinctly audible at a distance of 300 m (1 000 ft.), and
has a tone distinct from the whistles used by yarders or loaders in the vicinity.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 45.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Empty log transporter trailers, when loaded onto truck tractors, must be adequately secured against dislodgment.
If a worker is required to manually assist in coupling a trailer reach to a truck tractor of a log transporter, handholds or other devices must be installed on the trailer reach to aid the worker.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 139/2021, App. D, s. 13.]
An operator of a vehicle transporting workers in a forestry operation on a road must not overtake and pass a moving and loaded log transporter or low bed transport truck, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that operator receives a signal to proceed from the operator of the loaded log transporter or the operator of the low bed transport truck, and
the road conditions are suitable for that manoeuvre.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Roads, bridges, elevated platforms, and other structures used by vehicles transporting workers, logs or other forest products in forestry operations must be constructed and maintained to a standard which will permit safe transit.

Road or skid trail construction, including any blasting activity, must be carried out in a manner that prevents hangups, hanging broken tops or limbs, leaners, sidebind of pushed trees, or similar hazards which could endanger fallers or other workers.

The open sides of bridges, elevated truck weigh scales and associated elevated ramp approaches and other elevated structures used by logging trucks must be equipped with substantial and well secured continuous timber or log curbs or bull rails of sufficient height to prevent vehicles from running off the structure, but not less than 25 cm (10 in).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Dangerous trees, loose rocks, stumps, or other unstable materials that are hazardous to road users must be removed or cleared for a safe distance back from roadsides or roadside banks.

Brush, foliage or debris which prevents an adequate view by a vehicle operator of traffic approaching at roadway intersections or on sharp curves must be cleared and all possible precautions must otherwise be taken to control the hazards created by limited sight distance.
An effective traffic control system must be used by all vehicles on a section of road that is too narrow to permit 2 or more vehicles to pass.
The traffic control system must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: turnouts, where required,
vehicles operating with their headlights and, if fitted, flashing beacons, turned on,
warning signs where required, and
instructional signs, including kilometre and road name or number signs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Instructional signs must be posted showing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: radio channels on a road or a section of a road where radio channels are being used for traffic control, or
radio frequencies on a road or a section of a road where radio frequencies, but not radio channels, are being used for traffic control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. D, s. 32.]
Weight recording house structures, forming part of a log transporter weigh scale unit, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be sufficiently offset from the scale balance platform to provide an adequate margin for log load clearance, or
have an effective barrier erected between the weigh scale deck and the house.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A boat used in or about a forestry operation must be maintained in good mechanical and seaworthy condition.
A boat must be inspected daily before first use, and thereafter as required, and defects must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be reported immediately in writing to the supervisor, and
if they affect the safe operation of the boat, be remedied before the boat is used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A boat must be equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: effective machinery guarding that meets the requirements of this Regulation,
effective guards or insulation on hot exhaust pipes or stacks,
suitable cabins, screens or guards to protect operators against injury from towline breakage if the boats are regularly required to pull logs, booms or barges,

suitable cabins, screens, or guards meeting the requirements of WCB Standard G606, Boom Boat Operator Protective Structures if operators are subject to injury from logs or limbs intruding into the control area,
suitable hydraulic or other steering systems that will not transmit forces that could cause injury to the operator through feedback of rudder reaction,
deck matting or other surface cover which provides an effective grip for caulked footwear, and
effective heating.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A boat operated in navigable waters during the period from sunset to sunrise, or in conditions of restricted visibility, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 28 (b).]
have deck and cabin lighting, where necessary to provide safe levels of illumination aboard the craft, and
have searchlights or floodlights, where necessary to facilitate safe navigation and to illuminate working or boarding areas adjacent to the craft.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Buoyancy equipment meeting the requirements of Part 8 (Personal Protective Clothing and Equipment) must be worn by each worker on a boom boat or in an open boat.
A boat used for breaking down unstable groups of logs which are criss-crossed or difficult to break free must be of sufficient size to ensure that vessel stability is not compromised.
A boat must not be used to tow log booms or barges, that, by reason of weight, wind, current or sea conditions, are beyond the capacity of the towing craft to safely control.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A boat must not be loaded with personnel or equipment so as to adversely affect its stability or seaworthiness.

When a boat is used to push, pull or restrain log bundles during breaking operations, the operator must remain on the boat unless the boat is firmly securerd to the log bundles in a manner that allows the operator to get on and off safely.
A boat designed for use in calm waters must not be operated in wind or sea conditions that adversely affect its safe operation.
If the movement of a boat is regulated by hand signals, the code of signals authorized by the Board must be followed.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 52.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Log booms must be made up and sized with due regard for the size and quality of the available rigging.
Booming grounds must be of sufficient width to safely accommodate booms that are being worked on.
Booming grounds must be provided with safe access.
Booming chains, swifters and related items of rigging used in booming operations must be maintained in safe condition.
Rigging which is damaged or deteriorated enough to be a danger to workers must be removed from service.
The owner of the facility receiving a completed log boom must ensure that boomsticks are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stripped of excess rigging before they are returned into service, and
secured in a manner that will prevent entanglement during transit.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A boat that is used to make up or strip booms must use a winch appropriate to the task that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is capable of withstanding the maximum stress that could be imposed while moving log bundles, and
has a large enough diameter to hold all of the line that is needed to complete the task.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If boom stripping is done manually, a sufficient number of workers must be available to handle the rigging safely.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 60.]
A log or log bundle must not be dumped into water if there is a known or reasonably foreseeable risk to a worker.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 55.]

oasis:tcaption.oasis:line: Table 26-6: Requirements for radio controlled carriages

oasis:entry.oasis:line: • These carriages are fitted with and controlled by an onboard computerized radio control system. This radio system is operated independently through a transmitter separated from that of the yarder.

• The yarding and carriage frequencies must be separate, registered and coordinated through the WCB co-ordination system to ensure that one does not interfere with the other or with another operation. Contact the WCB for more information.
• An audible signal must be sounded at the carriage and not at the yarder. This signal must have a tone different from that of the yarder signal.
• Standard skyline signals will apply at the yarder.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies to workplaces that process logs or other wood into lumber, shakes, shingles, chips, plywood, particleboard or other wood products.

Equipment used to manufacture wood products must be designed or fitted with effective guarding or screening to protect workers from flying chips, debris, or hazards in the event of the failure of equipment components.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Edgers and other wood processing equipment which expose workers to the danger of material being thrown back by the saws must be fitted with effective kickback fingers, and if the danger remains when the kickback fingers are raised, a substantial barrier must be provided to protect workers.
A worker must not be in front of raised kickback fingers while the saw is in motion.
A worker must not be allowed at the outfeed end of an edger or other similar wood processing equipment where a kickout hazard exists, and inadvertent entry into such a danger area must be prevented.
Edgers equipped with automatically activated kickback fingers must have interlocks to prevent forward motion of the feed rolls while the kickback fingers are in a raised position.
Workers must be protected from the kickback or kickout dangers of plywood sanders.
Edger pressure rolls must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a solid continuous rim surface, and
be kept in contact with the material being cut.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Only one piece of material at a time may be fed into any single set of pressure rolls for an edger, surfacer, or planer.
A multiple feed edger must have separate pressure rolls for each feed.
A worker who is required to cross a green chain or transfer deck must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be instructed in the hazards and proper procedures to follow,
ensure the transfer deck is stopped before crossing, and is restarted only after the crossing is completed,
cross only on fully decked locations where no hazard of falling exists and where safe means of access and egress have been provided, and
cross only in a space clear of material.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a worker is required to access a transfer deck in order to control the flow of material as part of normal production work, the employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: safe work procedures are established and, where practicable, posted adjacent to the machinery,
the worker is instructed in and follows the safe work procedures,
the transfer deck is stopped before access,
the worker accesses only fully decked areas, where there is no hazard of falling and where safe access and egress has been provided, and
the stop control devices cannot be overridden by another control device, or by another worker.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a worker must access a lumber package rollcase for normal production work,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the rollcase must be stopped, and
the equipment and machinery must have effective safeguards to prevent injury to workers due to movement of material.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A mechanical handler must be effectively safeguarded to prevent contact by workers.
A veneer clipper must be guarded to prevent a worker's hands or fingers being placed under the knife.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A dry kiln must have effective safety devices to prevent a door or carrier from falling.
If a worker may be entrapped in a dry kiln, there must be an effective means of emergency escape, clearly identifiable by anyone inside the kiln.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A personnel hoist for a hot press, a pulp and paper dryer or a similar machine must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have effective means to prevent the platform from falling if the power or equipment fails,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 61 (a).]
have critical components regularly inspected by a qualified person,
have the rated load clearly marked on the hoist platform,
have a log of inspections, maintenance and repairs meeting the requirements of Part 4 (General Conditions), and
be fitted with guardrails and toeboards meeting the requirements of Part 4.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Where dangers, and dangerous equipment such as a jump saw, or automated equipment operated by photocells or proximity switches, are not readily visible to workers, the dangers must be made conspicuous by signs, placards or other effective means.
An effective means of communication must be provided and safe work procedures must be established to ensure the safety of workers when 2 or more workers are required to work as a team.
Water operations must meet the requirements for such operations in Part 26 (Forestry Operations and Similar Activities).
An unattended saw and other woodworking machinery must not be left running if a worker could be endangered.
Equipment used for grinding saws and knives must have an effective local exhaust ventilation system or other effective means of dust and mist control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Babbitt melting must be done at a controlled temperature.
Exhaust hoods must be provided for melting and pouring operations or an equally effective air contaminant control method must be used.
A babbitt pot must be covered.
If practicable, a lead-free babbitt must be used.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The cutting edges of saws, knives, cutting heads, and other sharp-edged devices, must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: guarded to prevent worker contact, when stored in operating areas, and
handled and transported in a manner which will not endanger workers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is a risk of injury to a worker from the blade of a circular saw, or flying debris from the saw blade, the portions of the blade outside the cutting area must be fully guarded.
Guards must be arranged to allow cutting with a minimum amount of exposed blade.
A band saw and its band wheels must be enclosed or otherwise effectively guarded except in the cutting area to prevent worker contact and to restrain the saw blade in the event of blade failure.
If metal enclosures are used with shake band saw wheels, the top door panel must be fitted with an inside wooden liner.
For a hand-fed shake band saw, the distance between the top of the table rollers and the top guide must not exceed 36 cm (14 in).
Barriers to protect workers from ejected material must be installed in front of and behind all multiple slashers and multiple trim saws.

If a worker may be caught or pulled into a saw or other danger area by a lug chain or similar transfer system, an emergency stopping device must be fitted on the conveyance to automatically stop the transfer system before the worker is pulled into the danger area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A circular cutoff saw must be fully enclosed, guarded, or located to prevent inadvertent contact with the running saw when it is in the retracted position.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a worker may be exposed to kickback from a circular saw with rip-type teeth, the saw must be fitted with an effective splitter.
Subsection (1) does not apply to an edger or circular resaw which is equipped with anti-kickback fingers.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chop, trim and swing cutoff saws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each swing cutoff saw must have

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a device to automatically return the saw to the back of the table,
a limit chain, or similar device to prevent the saw from swinging beyond the front of the table and past a position where the gullets of the lowest teeth rise above the top of the table, and
a latch or similar device to prevent saw rebound.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A swing cutoff saw operator must be positioned so that no part of the operator's body is in line with the saw.
Each chop, trim and swing cutoff saw must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be effectively guarded,
be guarded by location, or
have other effective means that prevent the operator's hands being placed in the cutting area when the saw is activated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Circular head saws and scragg saws must be equipped with safety guides.
If a top saw is only used occasionally, such as to cut flares off oversized logs, the requirements of subsection (1) do not apply.
Guides that must be adjusted while the saw is in motion must have the adjustment controls located away from the danger area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a powered conveyor feeds material at right angles to the blade of a circular cutoff saw, the system must have interlock control devices to prevent side loading of the saw.
Log and block cutoff saw operators must be positioned so that no part of the operator's body is in line with the saw unless adequate barriers have been installed.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 62.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A saw must be inspected frequently and maintained in a safe condition.
A dull, badly set, improperly filed or tensioned saw, or an inserted tooth saw with poorly fitting shanks or worn bits, must be removed from service.
A saw must be inspected for cracks and other defects each time the saw is sharpened, and a cracked saw must be removed from service until repaired by a qualified person.
A saw or saw collar damaged by excessive heat or undue stress must be removed from service until inspected and repaired by a qualified person.

A circular saw with a crack of any size adjacent to the collar line, or with a crack elsewhere which exceeds the limit specified in Table 27-1, must be removed from service until the crack is repaired and the saw retensioned by a qualified person.

A circular saw with a crack near the periphery which does not exceed the limit specified in Table 27-1 must be removed from service until the crack is repaired or the lengthening of the crack has been arrested by slotting, centre punching, drilling or other effective means, and the saw is retensioned as necessary, by a qualified person.

oasis:tcaption.oasis:line: Table 27-1: Circular saw crack limits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A band saw, other than a shake band saw, with a crack exceeding the limit specified in Table 27-2 must be removed from service until the crack is repaired and the saw retensioned by a qualified person.

A band saw, other than a shake band saw, with a crack not exceeding the limit specified in Table 27-2 must be removed from service until the crack is repaired or the lengthening of the crack has been arrested by centre punching or other effective means, and the saw retensioned as necessary, by a qualified person.
A shake band saw with a crack must not be used.

oasis:tcaption.oasis:line: Table 27-2: Band saw crack limits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise specified by the manufacturer or a professional engineer, the minimum rim thickness of a cast steel band saw wheel measured 25 mm (1 in) inboard from the rim edge must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 14 mm (9/16 in) for wheels up to and including 1.8 m (6 ft) diameter,
16 mm (5/8 in) for wheels over 1.8 m (6 ft) up to and including 2.75 m (9 ft) diameter, and
17.5 mm (11/16 in) for wheels over 2.75 m (9 ft) diameter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A band saw wheel over 1.2 m (48 in) diameter must be nondestructively tested for cracks by a qualified person at least once a year.
A cracked wheel or a wheel which has been exposed to excessive heat must be removed from service until the wheel manufacturer, or a professional engineer, has certified it as safe for continued use.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless clearly impracticable, every log-haul must have at least one walkway

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fitted with cleats and handrails, and
of sufficient width to enable workers to stand clear of logs in the log haul.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that, when log hauling and similar hoisting equipment is being used, workers are positioned so that they will not be endangered by logs as a result of power or equipment failure, or other similar cause during lifting and lowering operations.
Log hauling and similar hoisting equipment must be equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: devices which prevent logs from running back in the event of power failure, and
an emergency stop control by which the operator can stop the equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The emergency stop control must not be capable of being overridden.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Provisions must be made to protect workers from rolling logs.
Logs must be restrained against dangerous movement at the infeed and outfeed sections of a mechanical ring barker.
When wires, strapping, or bundling cables are removed from bundled logs in booming grounds, millyards or dryland sorting areas, the following requirements must be met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specific written safe work procedures must be developed and followed by all workers involved in the operation;
the load must be restrained to prevent logs or log chunks from rolling off the bundle, or otherwise endangering the workers;
workers must not be allowed beneath a suspended load or equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Substantial stops, preferably with spring, pneumatic, or hydraulic buffers, must be installed at each end of the carriage travel area.
The employer must ensure that means are provided and used to eliminate inadvertent operation of the headrig log-turning and carriage-feed controls.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a headrig sawyer may be exposed to the hazard of logs, sawn material, or chunks entering the booth or operator's area, the sawyer must be protected by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a substantial barrier between the sawyer and carriage track, extending from the floor of the booth to 60 cm (2 ft) above the rollcase, and
a substantial barrier at the log loading area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where necessary to deflect sawn material away from the sawyer, a substantial barrier must be installed between the sawyer booth and the saw.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Headrigs must have safety devices which prevent carriage equipment or dogs from contacting the saw or slabber head.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Hog and chipper feed chutes must be equipped with baffles or other effective means to prevent material from being thrown from the equipment.
A worker feeding or clearing a hog or chipper must be restrained by a safety belt and lanyard, unless otherwise protected from falling into the conveyor or machine.
Until the rotor has stopped turning, no attempt must be made to remove a guard, hood, shroud or inspection plate from a hog, chipper, or cutter head.
A makeshift device that may cause injury to a worker must not be used to brake or slow down a rotor or cutter head.
A mill chipper with a shroud, hood or inspection plate that can be removed before the rotor has stopped must have an effective brake.
Subsection (3) does not apply to a whole log chipper.
A hog or chipper must have a means of determining if rotating parts are in motion or have stopped.
A production planer installed after January 1, 1999 must be equipped with brakes on the heads, and all production planers must have brakes on the heads by January 1, 2000.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Height of chip and sawdust piles

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The height of any excavated or unstable face of a chip, hog fuel or sawdust pile must not exceed the safe reach of the mobile equipment being used to handle the material.
Workers unprotected by equipment or barriers must not enter a hazardous area near the face of a chip, hog fuel or sawdust pile.
A pile of lumber, veneer, plywood or similar wood product must be erected plumb and level, and be maintained in a stable condition.
Spacing blocks which permit stable piling and unobstructed access for the forks of lift trucks must be placed beneath each pile and between loads.

Veneer loads must be supported by at least 3 spacing blocks of sufficient size to permit stable piling and unobstructed access for the forks of lift trucks, and individual load height must not exceed 1 m (3.3 ft).
Loads of lumber built up for storage or transportation must be stabilized

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: using stripping material which, where feasible, does not protrude beyond the side of the load or package, or
by other effective means.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If wood products are piled on a foundation that is firm and level

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: loads of lumber may be piled up to approximately 4.5 m (15 ft) high,
unitized loads of lumber or loads of lumber 15 cm (6 in) or more in width may be piled up to approximately 6 m (20 ft) high, except for the outer pile which must not exceed 4.5 m (15 ft),
if 3 or more loads of any size lumber are cross-tied at each successive level, the loads may be piled up to approximately 11 m (35 ft) high,
veneer piled in the vicinity of passageways or work areas must be adequately supported to prevent falling,
veneer storage piles must not exceed 4.5 m (15 ft) high, and
loads of plywood and similar wood products may be piled up to approximately 6 m (20 ft) high except for the outer stack which must not exceed 4.5 m (15 ft).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Foot pedal controls on shake splitters and cubers must be fitted with effective guards to prevent inadvertent operation of the equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Blocks must be securely piled not more than one tier high when on the sawyer's table, and no higher than 1.8 m (6 ft) elsewhere.
Blocks must be of a size that does not interfere with the safe loading of the carriage jaws.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A shingle machine with a circular head saw must have a sawtooth guard which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: projects at least 38 mm (1 1/2 in) beyond the exposed cutting edge of the headsaw,
will prevent the headsaw leaving the arbor should the securing nut fail, and
is located and maintained not more than 13 mm (1/2 in) from the side of the saw.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A hand-fed shake resaw must have a substantial arm guard on the working side of the blade to prevent the operator from contacting the blade.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except for the portion that is exposed to trim shingles, a clipper saw must be effectively guarded by a substantial metal guard of at least 16 mm (5/8 in) diameter round stock, or a flat bar of equivalent strength, installed not more than 100 mm (4 in) above the saw and not more than 13 mm (1/2 in) from the plane of the saw.

Clipper saw boards must have substantial finger guards, not less than 130 mm (5 in) long and 32 mm (1 1/4 in) deep, designed and adjusted to prevent the operator's fingers from contacting any exposed saw teeth below the clipper board.

An independently motor driven clipper saw must be equipped with an effective braking device, automatically activated when the motor power ceases, and which is capable of bringing the saw to a stop in not more than 20 seconds.
Braking devices must be of a design acceptable to the Board.

A shingle machine jaw treadle must be arranged so that the operator must activate the clutch control to start the machine after the treadle is released, and the use of devices to permit the machine to automatically start when the jaw treadle is released is prohibited.
Shingle machine jaw treadles must be constructed of, or covered with, non-skid material.
Ratchet levers on the set works of a shingle cutting machine must be guarded.
Reciprocating parts of shingle machine carriage drives must be guarded to prevent contact by workers.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Conventional shingle machine carriage speed must not exceed 34 strokes per minute.
The head saw of a conventional shingle machine must have a minimum diameter of 1 m (39 in).
The employer must ensure that a worker does not leave a shingle machine or clipper saw unattended if the saw is in motion.
In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural operations include the production activities related to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apiculture,
berry farming,
Christmas tree culture,
composting,
dairy farming,
egg farming,
forest seedling and seed production,
grain and oilseed production,
greenhouse operations,
herb production,
horticulture, including floriculture, tree nurseries and ornamental nurseries,
insects raised for biological pest control,
orchards,
poultry farming,
a riding academy, or the boarding or breeding of horses,
seed production,
sod or turf production,
vegetable farming,
wool, hide, feather or fur production, and
the raising of crops or animals for human or animal consumption,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but do not include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the production of agricultural byproducts or of manufactured derivatives from agricultural raw material,
the breeding or raising of pets other than horses, or
aquaculture;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural tractor means a vehicle, with more than 20 engine horsepower, running on wheels, designed to furnish the power to pull, carry, propel or drive an implement that is designed or used for agriculture, but does not include a self-propelled implement;
farm land means land used for agricultural operations;
low-profile tractor means an agricultural tractor with the following characteristics:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the front wheel spacing is equal to the rear wheel spacing, as measured from the centre line of each right wheel to the centre line of the corresponding left wheel;
the clearance from the bottom of the tractor chassis to the ground does not exceed 46 cm (18 in);
the highest point of the hood does not exceed 1.5 m (60 in);
the tractor is designed so that the operator straddles the transmission when seated;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: orchard ladder means a self-supporting portable ladder of the tripod type, wide at the bottom and tapering towards the top, non-adjustable in length, and consisting of side rails, flat steps and a hinged, single leg back section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies to agricultural operations on farm land.
Cold storage rooms must have at least one door that can, at all times, be opened from inside the room.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Bridges and culverts under roadways within the agricultural workplace must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designed, constructed and maintained so as to safely support the heaviest load expected to be imposed on them, and
of sufficient width to permit equipment and machinery to cross safely.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bridge within the agricultural workplace must also be provided with bullrails not less than 25 cm (10 in) in height.
Where manure or other material is loaded into pits by self-propelled equipment, the employer must install barriers sufficient to prevent the equipment from falling or inadvertently entering the pit.
If the use of barriers required by subsection (1) is not practicable, the employer must adopt procedures that provide equivalent protection for workers.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Instruction of seasonal, temporary and other workers
bcl:section.bcl:text: When workers, including seasonal and temporary workers, start employment, the employer and the employer's supervisor must ensure that they are instructed about the safe performance of their duties.

If an agricultural tractor is proposed to be used without a ROPS under section 16.34 (2) (b), in addition to the factors listed in section 16.34 (1) to be considered in the rollover risk assessment, the qualified person must also consider the training and experience of the operator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that workers have a safe means of escape from any enclosure occupied by animals that are potentially dangerous to workers.
If a worker is required to handle animals, the employer must ensure that the worker is effectively instructed and trained and is competent to perform the assigned work.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 4.70 to 4.80 (Indoor air quality) do not apply to a private residence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Control of environmental tobacco smoke and e-cigarette vapour exception
bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 4.81 and 4.82 (Environmental tobacco smoke and e-cigarette vapour) do not apply in a private residence, except when a worker, other than the occupant of the residence, is working in the residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that an adequate supply of potable drinking water is available to workers during the workday.
Water in irrigation ditches or other similar sources is not potable drinking water for the purposes of subsection (1).
If drinking water is provided in portable dispensers, the dispensers must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: equipped with a tap,
capable of being covered, and
maintained in a sanitary condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Workers must be informed of any water supplies that are unsafe to drink.
Section 5.82 (2) (a) and (b) does not apply to agricultural operations on farm land.

If work processes involving substances such as lead, mercury, asbestos, silica or pesticides are high hazard, the employer must ensure that workers are provided with adequate and appropriate shower and change facilities.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 199/2014, App. J, s. 1.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 6.116 to 6.132 (Toxic process gases) do not apply to anhydrous ammonia fertilization systems.
If anhydrous ammonia is stored or used for the purpose of fertilization, the employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment containing anhydrous ammonia is inspected before each use, to prevent accidental leakage or spillage,
the hose end-valves are in the closed position when the equipment is not operating, and
the relief and vapour valves are positioned so that any discharge is directed upwards and away from the worker's operating position.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ventilation of buildings near manure tanks

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not enter or remain in a building or structure adjoining a liquid manure tank while the manure is being agitated.
Following agitation of the manure, any adjoining building or structure must be thoroughly ventilated before a worker is permitted to re-enter it.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 8.23 (Non-slip footwear) does not apply to a work activity involving horseback riding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warning signs for power take-off devices
bcl:section.bcl:text: At conspicuous locations near rotating shafts driven by power take-off devices, warning signs must be located specifying that shields must be kept in place.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Signs and procedures for equipment guarding
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the removal of a guard or access door would expose a worker to a component that continues to rotate after the power to the component has been disengaged,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the employer must apply a sign to the guard or access door warning of the danger, and
the guard must not be removed or access door opened until enough time has elapsed to bring all components to a complete stop.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A worker using a hay baler must not attempt to clear hay from the collection area unless the engine is stopped and cannot be inadvertently started.
A worker must keep clear of the discharge area of a round baler and the area under the hatch unless the hatch is blocked open.
A post-hole digger must have

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tractor or machine brakes set before digging,
shear bolts as specified by the manufacturer, and
a hold-to-run control when operated as a hand-held unit.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A worker operating a post driver must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lower the hammer and stop the engine when adjustment or maintenance is required,
if necessary for safety, steady the post with a steady fork or guide, and
lower or block the hammer when the machine is not in use.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 12.72 does not apply to a chain saw used in agricultural operations on farm land, if the chain saw was purchased for first use before December 31, 1993.
A hand winch for raising an auger conveyor must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a control that will hold the auger at any angle, and
respond only when the handle is turned.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alternative means of evaluation for automotive lifts and vehicle supports

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 12.76, if written instructions are not available from the manufacturer or a professional engineer, the instructions may be provided instead by any other person qualified to develop them.

Despite sections 4.8 and 12.79, if a modification is made to a device listed in section 12.79 (1) or if the manufacturer's rated capacity is not known, the rated capacity may be determined by a person qualified to do so.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 13.2 (1) and 13.5 (a), (b) and (c) do not apply to orchard ladders.
An orchard ladder must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meet the construction requirements of CSA Standard CAN3-Z11-M81, Portable Ladders, except that the spreader requirement does not apply to orchard ladders,
have a rail spread that increases at least an average of 6 cm (2.5 in) for each 30 cm (12 in) of ladder length, and
when necessary for safety, have the feet of the ladder equipped with steel points or other non-slipping bases designed for the ground on which the ladder will be used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ladder used is appropriate for the task, and
a worker using an orchard ladder is instructed in its proper use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 422/2004, s. 4.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 13.2 (1) (a), a fixed ladder existing on or before January 1, 2006, and not conforming to the current or an earlier edition of ANSI Standard A14.3-1992, Safety Requirements for Fixed Ladders, may remain in use subject to any modifications considered necessary by the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 14.2 to 14.33 and 14.44 do not apply to a job built crane or hoist for use on site with a rated capacity of less than 1 tonne (2 200 lbs) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the device is built or otherwise assembled by a person qualified to do the work,
the rated capacity of the device, including support structures, is determined by a person qualified to make the assessment,
the rated capacity is marked on the device and is not exceeded,
the device is not used to support a worker,
the device is operated so that a worker is not under the load,

the device is inspected and maintained at a frequency and to the extent required to ensure that every component is capable of carrying out its original design function with an adequate margin of safety,
inspection and maintenance records are maintained for the device consistent with Part 4 (General Conditions), and
any modifications to the device are made by a person qualified to do the work.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the Board may require compliance with sections 14.2 to 14.33 and 14.44 if the design of the equipment or the circumstances of use indicate the need.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Altered application dates for cranes and hoists

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The certification of drop stops required under section 14.19 (2) must be completed by January 1, 2006.
Section 14.54 applies to a bridge, overhead or gantry crane, if installed after January 1, 2006, or to a crane or its runway if it is modified after that date.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The requirements for identification of various rigging components in sections 15.5, 15.24 (3), 15.42, 15.46, 15.52, 15.55 and 15.59 may also be met if the employer is able to determine the information required for a particular device by any means of identification specific to it.
The requirements of sections 15.6 (2), 15.27, 15.28 (1), 15.32 and 15.36 for the competency of a person evaluating a device may be met by a person who is qualified to conduct the evaluation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 139/2021, App. D, s. 15.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for mobile elevating work platforms
bcl:section.bcl:text: A mobile elevating work platform used in an orchard must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a platform equipped with a non-skid surface,
be provided with a drive system that ensures there will be no unintended movement of the unit, and
not be operated on sloping ground unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specific instructions from the manufacturer for the operation are followed, and
the unit is equipped with a braking system capable of restraining the machine under any condition of use, or the unit is equipped with wheels that will not turn unless driven.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Mobile elevating work platform design standards

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided by subsection (2), a mobile elevating work platform used in an orchard must meet the requirements of section 13.2 (1).
A mobile elevating work platform may be used in an orchard if it has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a platform equipped with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a gate that does not swing outward and that can be securely fastened in the closed position to minimize the risk of accidental opening,
a top rail approximately 90 cm (36 in) in height above the floor and capable of withstanding a load of 890 N (200 lbs) applied in any direction at any point on the top rail, and
a toe rail, on the sides not serviced by a gate, which is approximately 8 cm (3 in) in height with a maximum clearance between the floor and the bottom edge of the toe rail of 5 cm (2 in), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for equipment manufactured after December 31, 1993, a maximum platform height of 3.6 m (12 ft).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Identification on mobile elevating work platforms
bcl:section.bcl:text: A mobile elevating work platform used in orchards, if manufactured after December 31, 1993, must have the following information permanently and conspicuously marked on it:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: certification to confirm the standard met by the device;
the make, model, serial number and manufacturer's name;
the rated platform workload;
the maximum platform height and travel height;
the maximum slope on which the device may be operated when the platform is elevated.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 13.33 (1) and Part 11 (Fall Protection) do not apply to a worker using a mobile elevating work platform in an orchard if the platform height is 3.6 m (12 ft) or less.

For the purposes of application of sections 13.12 and 13.23 (1) (b), a person may make the inspection and determination of safety for continued use of a mobile elevating work platform used in orchards if the person is qualified to do so, and the work platform has a maximum operational height of 3.6 m (12 ft).
Sections 13.24 (2), 13.25 and 13.26 do not apply to mobile elevating work platforms when they are used in orchards at a height of 3.6 m (12 ft) or less.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 139/2021, App. D, s. 15.]
Despite sections 16.8 and 16.20 and Part 17, a person other than the operator may be transported on mobile equipment that is not designed for the transportation of workers, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is safely seated, and
the mobile equipment is operated at no more than 10 km/h (6 mph).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 3.]
This Part applies to the use of aircraft in the workplace.
The employer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide written safe work procedures for workers who are exposed to hazards from aircraft operations,
ensure that workers are provided with adequate pre-job instruction and that the instruction is documented, and
ensure that workers can demonstrate the ability to safely perform their tasks as required.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 4.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that effective communication between air and ground crews has been established before initiating airlift operations.
If hand signals are used to communicate between air and ground crews

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only internationally recognized hand signals may be used,
the designated signaller must be identified to the pilot in command by means of high visibility apparel and position, and
all workers exposed to hazards from the airlifting operation must know and understand the hand signals.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 5.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that airlifted loads are not flown over workers.
Workers must remain clear and in recognized safe areas when there is a hazard from airlifted loads.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that effective traffic control measures are employed as required by Part 18 (Traffic Control) wherever airlifted loads will be flown over travelled roadways.
The employer must ensure that helicopter rotorwash will not expose workers to undue risk.
The employer must ensure that work areas are planned and maintained to avoid placing workers in hazardous proximity to unstable materials.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 6.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner, or the person engaged by the owner to be the prime contractor, must give notice to the Board at least 2 weeks before commencing any operation involving aerial transport of logs or other products made of wood.
The notice must provide the

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: name of the prime contractor and of the person responsible for the operation,
location, scheduled start date and expected duration of the operation, and
type of logging activity to be done.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must assign a person on site the responsibility for supervising and coordinating airlift operations.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 7.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Log loading areas must be separate from drop zones.
Before accessing loading and drop zone areas, workers must communicate their intentions to aircraft and equipment operators, and get an "all clear" signal to proceed from the operators.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. H, s. 8.]
A flagperson who may be exposed to pesticide spray or drift must wear protective clothing covering the head, body, hands and feet, and a respirator appropriate for the pesticide being applied.
In this Part, biological agent means a biological agent designated as a hazardous substance under section 5.1.1.

This Part applies to rooms, buildings or areas in buildings equipped with apparatus, equipment, chemicals or test animals and used for research, quality control, performance of tests, experiments or measurements, photographic development, or the preparation of drugs or other products in the natural sciences.
Operators of laboratory equipment must be adequately instructed and trained in the safe use of laboratory equipment and the precautions to be taken when the equipment is used.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 29.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Laboratory water faucets with goosenecks must be protected by vacuum breaks meeting the requirements of ANSI Standard ANSI/ASSE 1001-1990, Pipe Applied Atmospheric Type Vacuum Breakers.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 64 (b).]
The location of an in-line vacuum break must be clearly identified.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 30.]
Suitable fire extinguishers of a size easily handled by laboratory workers must be immediately accessible wherever flammable materials are used or stored.
Laboratory equipment which presents a physical hazard to workers must be adequately guarded, shielded or isolated by location.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. D, s. 33.]
Hazards of equipment use must be identified on the equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Laboratory equipment and instruments which may emit harmful quantities of a substance during their operation must be provided with an effective local exhaust ventilation system.
In sections 30.8 to 30.11:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: laboratory fume hood means an enclosed and mechanically ventilated workspace located in a laboratory, that is designed to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: draw air into the workspace and to prevent or minimize the escape of airborne contaminants out of the workspace, and
allow a worker to conduct physical, chemical and biological manipulations inside the workspace;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: operational face opening means an opening in a laboratory fume hood through which a worker may conduct work inside the hood;

sash means a vertical or horizontal panel on a laboratory fume hood that defines the operational face opening and provides a protective barrier between the worker conducting work inside the hood and the contents of the hood.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A laboratory fume hood and its related ductwork must be designed, installed and maintained in accordance with the Industrial Ventilation, A Manual of Recommended Practice, published by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, as amended from time to time.
A laboratory fume hood must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be connected to a local exhaust ventilation system,
provide average face velocities of 0.4 m/s (80 fpm) to 0.6 m/s (120 fpm) across the operational face opening,
not have face velocities of less than 80% of the average face velocity required in paragraph (b) at any point across its operational face opening, and
not have face velocities of more than 120% of the average face velocity required in paragraph (b) at any point across its operational face opening.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A laboratory fume hood must have a sash that is positioned to protect the upper body and face of a worker working in the laboratory fume hood from accidental releases of the contents of the hood while allowing hand and arm access to equipment inside the hood.

A laboratory fume hood with a movable sash must be clearly marked to identify the maximum size of the operational face opening that will maintain the average face velocities required in subsection (2) (b).
The employer must ensure

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that before it is used, a commercially manufactured laboratory fume hood has been certified as being tested by the manufacturer, and
following installation and before it is used, a custom built laboratory fume hood is tested on site by a qualified person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A laboratory fume hood tested under subsection (2.3) must demonstrate containment not greater than the control level of 0.05 ppm when tested under "as manufactured" test conditions in accordance with the methods described in ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 110-1995, Method of Testing Performance of Laboratory Fume Hoods.
The installation of a laboratory fume hood must be certified by a professional engineer.
A laboratory fume hood must be located to prevent cross drafts or other disruptive forces from lowering the air flow across the operational face opening to unacceptable levels.
A laboratory fume hood and its ductwork must be constructed from materials compatible with its use.
A laboratory fume hood that will be or is being used for working with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: radioactive material in amounts that exceed the exemption quantity specified by the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission, or
perchloric acid

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be clearly labelled with applicable restrictions on its use.
A laboratory fume hood must not be used for storage of chemicals unless it is used exclusively for this purpose and is labelled with this limitation.
Controls for the operation of a laboratory fume hood and its service fixtures must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: located on the outside of the laboratory fume hood, and
immediately accessible to the worker conducting work in the laboratory fume hood.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (7), water taps may be located inside a laboratory fume hood if the main shutoff valve for the water is located outside the laboratory fume hood.
Equipment being used in a laboratory fume hood must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be kept at least 15 cm (6 in.) from the operational face opening of the laboratory fume hood, and
not adversely affect airflow into the laboratory fume hood.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Written procedures must be developed and implemented to ensure safe use and operation of a laboratory fume hood.
Face velocities over the operational face opening of a laboratory fume hood must be quantitatively measured and recorded.
The ability of a laboratory fume hood to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintain an inward flow of air across the operational face opening, and
contain contaminants

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be assessed and recorded using a smoke tube or other suitable qualitative method.
The actions described in subsections (1) and (2) must be performed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: after the laboratory fume hood is installed and before it is used,
at least once in each 12 month period after installation, and
after any repair or maintenance that could affect the air flow of the hood.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a laboratory fume hood is found to be operating with an average face velocity of less than 90% of the average face velocity required in section 30.8 (2), the employer must immediately take corrective action to bring the average face velocity within the required range of velocities.
Airflow in a laboratory fume hood must be monitored continuously if loss of airflow will result in risk to a worker.

A laboratory fume hood that is being installed must have an alarm capable of indicating when the average face velocity falls below the minimum average face velocity level required in section 30.8 (2) when the hood is in use.
Laboratory fume hoods located in the same room or separate rooms may be connected to a common exhaust duct or manifold system if the following conditions are satisfied:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the requirements of section 5.3.2 of ANSI/AIHA Standard Z9.5-2003, Laboratory Ventilation are met;
controls to prevent backdrafts and pressure imbalances between rooms are installed;
the ventilation design and installation of the common exhaust duct or manifold system is certified by a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), laboratory fume hoods that are or will be used for working with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: radioactive materials in amounts that exceed the exemption quantity specified by the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission, or
perchloric acid

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must not be connected to a manifold system.
Ducting used in the installation of a laboratory fume hood must be designed in accordance with established engineering principles.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Laboratory fume hood local exhaust ventilation systems must discharge to the atmosphere in such a manner that the discharged air will not be recirculated into the laboratory or other work areas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The limitations of a biological safety cabinet must be clearly posted on the unit and followed by workers.
Biological safety cabinets must be certified by a qualified person at least annually and before use after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: initial installation,
change of the HEPA (high efficiency particulate air) filter,
moving of the unit, and
any repair or maintenance that could affect the seal of the HEPA filter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Certification procedures used for compliance with subsection (2) must meet the requirements of the National Sanitation Foundation (NSF) Standard 49-2002, Class II (Laminar Flow) Biohazard Cabinetry, and a record of the results must be maintained.

Recirculation of exhaust air into a workspace from a biological safety cabinet is not permitted where volatile toxic materials or flammable liquids or gases are used in the cabinet, or where volatile radioactive materials are used in amounts that exceed the exemption quantity specified by the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 319/2007, App. B, s. 6 (c).]

Biological safety cabinets used for handling a biological agent must be operated and ventilated in accordance with the Laboratory Biosafety Guidelines 3rd edition, 2004, issued by the Public Health Agency of Canada.
Centrifuge loads must be balanced by sample distribution.

Aerosol-proof safety heads or cups or other equally effective means to prevent exposure of workers must be used where an aerosol containing a biological agent may be generated, where carcinogens are present or where radioactive samples pose a hazard to workers.
Unless exempted by CSA Standard C22.2 No. 151-M1986 Laboratory Equipment, or other standard acceptable to the Board, centrifuge doors must be interlocked to prevent workers accessing spinning rotors.

The interlock required by subsection (3) must prevent the door from opening while the rotor is spinning or cause the rotor to brake if the door is opened, or another equally effective means must be used to prevent a worker from accessing the spinning rotor.
Spent as of January 1, 2001.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 66.]
Rotors must be stored in a manner which will prevent them from being damaged.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Written safe work procedures must be prepared for hazardous operations, including work methods involving hazardous chemicals, spill response, and handling of a material that contains a biological agent, and workers must be adequately instructed in and follow the procedures.
Only the minimum necessary amount of biological agents and substances that are combustible, flammable, corrosive, toxic or highly reactive may be kept in the working area of the laboratory.

The transport of containers of flammable, corrosive, toxic or highly reactive substances or biological agents through a laboratory must be done in a manner that will not pose a danger of damage to the containers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must wear protective laboratory clothing in a laboratory where a toxic or radioactive substance or a biological agent is handled.
Protective laboratory clothing worn in circumstances referred to in subsection (1) must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be worn outside an area where a worker is required to wear the protective work clothing, and
be stored in a manner or location that might expose a worker to a hazardous substance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Smoking, eating or drinking is not permitted in any laboratory area.
Food for consumption must not be kept in the laboratory, and laboratory glassware, vessels and containers must not be used to prepare or store food or beverages for consumption.
Substances must not be pipetted by mouth.
If hazardous chemicals or materials are handled, all affected workers must receive instruction and training in the proper handling and disposal of such materials.

Accidental release or spills of chemicals or other hazardous substances must be controlled immediately, and cleaned up under the supervision of persons knowledgeable in the hazards involved and the precautions to be taken during the cleanup operations.
Personal protective equipment required during emergency cleanup or escape must be kept immediately available.
Laboratory waste must be disposed of in a manner which ensures that workers are protected from injury.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. E, s. 31 (b).]
Before disposal, organic solvents and flammable wastes must be collected in separate, tightly covered containers or in an equally effective manner.
Before disposal, water solutions containing azides must first be inactivated, and contact with heavy metals or other incompatible contaminants must be prevented.
Waste material that contains a biological agent must be collected in separate, tightly covered containers before disposal.
Containers of segregated waste must be clearly identified as to their intended use.
